text:
I can't rave about this recipe enough!  It was absolutely fabulous!  I only added about 1 1/2 pks of the spinach, and mixed the spinach, ricotta & chicken together for easy layering.  I used fresh (refrigerated), no-boil noodles and just let them cook in the sauce.  I did add about 1/2 cup white wine to the sauce and added a lot more garlic.  I did add almost twice the amount of ricotta and added a few extra cups of mozzerella.  (There's no such thing as too much cheese in my house:) My husband and friend who came over for dinner couldn't get enough!.  Definitely elegant and interesting enough to serve at a dinner party, but great for any family dinner as well.  I was just really pleased with this meal.

**Addendum 8/24/04--I just wanted to add that recently I began using fresh spinach in this recipe and it improved greatly.  I de-stemmed the spinach (about 1 lb bag) and then threw it in a pan with 1 tablespoon olive oil.  Cooked it down until it was tender and bright green.  The frozen spinach is mostly stems, so substituting fresh spinach took care of that problem

text:
my sister absolutely loves this dish! whenever she comes to visit from college, she begs me to make it. to kick up the flavor in the chicken, i marinate it overnight in a combination of roasted garlic (garlic drizzled w/ olive oil and put in the oven until it's soft and sweet), FRESH basil (nothing compares to the flavor) olive oil, and a splash of lemon juice. then i grill the chicken for additional flavor. it really makes it rustic. I add a layer of sauteed veggies (onion, garlic, fresh garlic, mushrooms, matchstick carrots, and zucchini). Mine ends up going: sauce, noodles, ricotta/spinich mixture, chicken, sauce, noodles, ricotta/spinich, veggies, sauce, noodles, ricotta/spinich, chicken, sauce, cheese. It is so good!

text:
The only way I could describe this dish is havenly.  It is pretty rich though so I won't be making it often and I felt like I dirtied every pan I own.  I made a few adjustments and have a few more that I will try next time I make it.
For the sauce I added about two teaspoons of chopped garlic from a jar and thought it was perfect.  I didn't chop my onions fine enough though.  I recommend you chop them very fine.  I only had one 10 oz can of chicken broth so I made up the rest of the two cups of broth with white wine.  I used the amount of oregano and basil called for and thought that was perfect.  But the wine may have hidden some of the taste.  I added salt and pepper at the very end based on taste.  I am not sure how much I added.
The recipe is not clear if the noodles should be precooked, so I used no bake noodles.  
I baked the chicken in the oven with no spices.  The chicken itself didn't have much flavor, but you don't miss it with everything else going on.
I used a 16 oz package of spinach and was still a little too much in my opinion.  Next time I will use one 10 oz package.
I didn't pay attention to how the recipe said to layer, because it didn't make any sense to me.  I put a third of the sauce in the pan, a layer of noodles, half of the chicken, spinach, and ricotta.  Then another layer of noodles, 1/3 of the sauce, rest of the chicken, spinach and ricotta.  The final layer of noodles and sauce.  Then the mozzerella and parm. cheese.  
Because I made ahead of

This was wonderful.  I made the following modifications:  made 1/3 more sauce.  Used only 1 package of spinach, which I mixed into the ricotta.  I layered in the following way:  1/4 sauce, 3 noodles, 1/2 ricotta/spinach, 1/2 chicken, 1/4 of sauce, 1/3 of remaining mozz/parm, 3 noodles, rest of ricotta/spinach, rest of chicken, 1/4 of sauce, 1/3 of remaining mozz/parm, 3 noodles, rest of sauce, rest of mozz/parm, sprinkled with fresh parsley.

text:
This was fabulous!  My husband enjoyed it so much he took leftovers for lunch the next day.  I did cook 1/2 lb of chopped bacon until crisp, remove and drain on some paper towel.  I then cooked 2 chopped raw chicken breast in the bacon grease until slightly brown and done and then drained on paper towels.  Giving the chicken a slight bacony flavour.  Then in layering I sprinkled the cooked bacon over the layer of spinach. It was great.  It combined one of my favourite combinations, a classic, chicken, bacon and spinach.  You must try adding the bacon.

text:
This was okay and I will make it again but I think it needs some tweaking to make it really good.  Next time, I will use a straight bechamel, using all milk and no chicken broth. I will probably use just parmesan cheese and skip the mozzarella, too. I think part of the reason I found this recipe so bland was that there was no nutmeg in the white sauce - for me nutmeg is a must, both for the bechamel AND for the spinach! Besides all the issues I had with the sauce, I made a couple changes to the "structure" of the lasagna - first putting sauce in the pan, then noodles, chicken with sauce, noodles, spinach with ricotta (I substituted cottage cheese), noodles, then the chicken mixture again, noodles, then the spinach mixture again, more noodles, finishing with plain sauce topped with more parmesan cheese. I used no-boil soft lasagna noodles throughout. I like to make lasagna on "swim lesson night" because I can make it ahead and have it bake and set before we get home, and my daughter doesn't like tomato-based lasagna so I will definitely make chicken and spinach lasagna again, but next time I'll do it "my way"...

text:
Wow!  This recipe is awesome!  My entire family raved--and they are fussy eaters!  Modifications:  I used chicken tenders and poached them, then shredded them (used about 3c.shredded chicken); strained poaching liquid and added 2 chicken bouillon cubes to 3c liquid (stay with me here) instead of the 2c canned broth, added about 1/2c more milk plus that extra cup broth BECAUSE I used no-boil lasagna noodles.  Sauce consistency was PERFECT!!!  I also covered pan with foil and baked about 45-50 minutes, and let it stand without foil outside oven about 10 minutes to "set up".  Yummmmmmm!

text:
Wonderful recipe, especially for cheese lovers. After scoring through the reviews and baking it myself, I have the following suggestions: 1. If you are using no boil lasagna noodles, add 1/2 cup more milk to the sauce. 2. Saute one pound of mushrooms in some butter and then saute FRESH spinach in the same pot. The  mushrooms nicely accent the spinach layer and add some flare. 3. Use THREE cups of chicken. (I used Tyson ready to serve grilled slices that I chopped up with scissors). 4. Instead of just shredded mozzarella, use a six cheese Italian blend. Very filling and decadent meal. I cut this into 12 pieces and 1/12th was more than enough per person.

text:
Because I liked the ingredients in this recipe, I decided to give it a try, but modified it to make it easier to make.  This is what I did and it turned out great:  Instead of lasagna noodles, I used a lb. of rotini.  (I HATE cooking lasagna noodles, don't ask me why).  I cooked the pasta while the chicken was boiling.  I used 4 boneless skinless chicken breasts and chopped them up when they were done boiling.  At the same time the pasta and chicken were cooking, I defrosted the spinach in the microwave and pressed all the moisture out of it.  I mixed the chicken, pasta, and spinach all together in the pasta pot after I drained off the pasta.  I seasoned it with the oregano, a little basil, salt, and pepper.  I made the cheese sauce as directed and added a little nutmeg to the sauce when it was done.  If you have one of those little choppers, I highly recommend using it to finely mince your onions and garlic.  Then, I added two eggs to the ricotta cheese along with a little bit of parmesan cheese, about 1/4 cup.  To assemble this recipe, I layered pasta mixture, ricotta, and cheese sauce in that order ending up with cheese sauce.  I then covered the top with mozzarella cheese and sprinkled on a bit of parmesan, popped it into the oven and baked it for 35 minutes.  This way is much easier for my kiddos to eat and I feel the ingredients blend together better this way.  It all fit very nicely in a 9x13 pan.  We will definately be making this again.  The taste was awesome!  The o

text:
this was SO good (i'd give it 5 stars but i did make changes).
i did halve the spinach as suggested and i'm glad i did, that would have been WAY too much spinach (however, one should note that the typical frozen spinach packages that say they are 300grams/10oz do NOT equal out to be that much when all the water is squeezed out of them, at least not in my case. to get just 10oz i needed to use 3-300gram packages of spinach. i usually squeeze out all the water and weigh the spinach afterwards).
i also cut up and fried some chicken breast in olive oil with salt,pepper, garlic and onion powder to give the chicken flavor (i really wouldn't advise having just plain chicken in it).
i also cooked some mushrooms with the onion and garlic (added 2 extra cloves as well) and then added the chicken in as well. i have made this dish with no chicken as well and i actually prefer it better that way.
i also mixed the spinach with the ricotta cheese and added some pepper to it. (so the layering was sauce, noodles, spinach mixture, sauce, mozzarella cheese, noodles, spinach mixture, sauce, mozzarella cheese, noodles, sauce, parmesan cheese and mozzarella cheese). 
it was really really good. even my partner liked it and she doesn't like spinach usually!. i didn't find it to be too thick at all and it heated up great later. 

make sure to drain your spinach very very well!

text:
My family and I love this recipe. I make two 7 1/2 x 9 1/2 baking dishes. We eat one and freeze the other for the future. The only change I make to this dish is I use 1 pound boneless, skinless, chicken breast cut into bite size pieces. After I pan fry the chicken, I mix the chicken, spinach, ricotta cheese, 2 cups mozzarella cheese and 1/2 cup Parmesan cheese together in a large bowl. It made everything a lot easier. I spread 1 cup sauce on bottom, layer with noodles, 2 cups chicken mixture, noodles, 1 cup sauce, 2 cups chicken mixture, noodles, last cup sauce. Sprinkle with parsley and 1/4 cup Parmesan cheese on top.

text:
This was so yummy!  My whole family loved it and it's really harty...will likely get 3 meals out of 1 pan! I made this mostly as stated, but after reading reviews of this being dry, bland and too cheesey/spinachy I made a couple small mods. (Bear with me, this is gonna be wordy, but it really seems to solve a lot of problems.)  I used 2 cups milk, only 1 pkg of spinach and only about 2 cups of cheese. I also did the layering just a little differently. After making the white sauce I divided it in 1/2. To one half I added the chicken and 1 cup of cheese (old Cheddar to give it a little more zip) and I used the other half to coat my pan and for the final layer of noodles. To the ricotta I added the spinach, salt and 1/2 cup parm. The layering went like this: Sauce (without chicken), noodles, ricotta/spinach mixture, noodles, sauce (with chicken), noodles, sauce (without chicken), topped with parm and mozza. The end result was moist, rich, perfectly seasoned and sinfully delicious! Can't wait till tomorrow to get my hands on those leftovers!

text:
I tried this recipe today, it was really delicious, it came out perfect even though it's my first time to do a lasagna ;) I read alot of the reviews before I started cooking to see if there were interesting tips that I could try out :) OK, so this is how I did it, first  I used fresh spinach instead of frozen, but I definitely went through all the fuss of de-stemming, steaming, chopping, then cooking it with little bit of better :) I also added white mushrooms, and for next time I will definitely use more of it, I cooked the mushrooms with the spinach then added the ricotta cheese on them, so it became the mushroom-spinach-ricotta mixture (and I considered it as a layer), also I took the advice of adding more garlic but not too much and also increasing the amount of the sauce mixture (by increasing the amount of chicken broth and milk but not too much), For the chicken layer, I choose to mix it with the cheesy sauce, so the chicken feels softer and juicier, plus I grilled the chicken instead of just cooking it, to give some twist in the taste, as some reviewers suggested, that's all the additions I did, This recipe is definitely a KEEPER, BTW: this is my first review on allrecipes, and it feels good to share your thoughts and experiences on cooking :)

I only changed it a little, I substituted cottage cheese for the ricotta cheese, and I added a zucchini and mushrooms to the spinach layer. text:
I cant for the life of me understand why members constantly change an original recipe to what suits their personal taste, and rate it low.

Sorry folks but you aren't helping others who want to know how the original recipe was. 
Isn't that what a review is? A review of the posted recipe?

If you like your version better than the original, than post your full recipe on the board so you can share it with others. 

You're not being honest and fair to the person who took the time to share a great recipe (with us), you tweak it to your personal preferences, and then rate it low because it didn't come out good. Doesn't make sense because you are rating your own recipe if you make changes and rate it as though its the original, when it is not.

text:
On the advice of others, I increased the garlic and spices, and only used 1 bag of fresh spinach.  Used no-boil lasagna noodles and increased milk to 2 c.  After cooking time was up, I broiled for a minute to crisp and brown the top layer of cheese.  It needs to sit for 20 minutes before cutting.  This allows the cheeses to hold everything together.  This is a great dish to make for guests ... put it together early in the day and no last minute cooking!  Turned out great.

Display Name:
Sarah Jo

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Phew. Complex recipe! I did change a couple things only because I spent some time reading the reviews and taking what I thought would be beneficial. I used the whole box of lasagna noodles, used all chicken broth in the sauce excepting a half cup of white wine. I also doubled the garlic and minced my onions really fine. Fred Meyer/Krogers had an italian mix of cheese (parmesan, mozzerella and provolone) on sale for a buck each so I used two packages of that, to save a little time. I also used cottage cheese instead of ricotta because....we'll.....we don't like ricotta AND I'm cheap. In the cottage cheese mixture, I added a little more basil and oregano. I only made two layers and the layers went sauce, noodles, cottage cheese/cheese mixture, spinach then chicken. It made it easier because all I had to do is divide everything in half. This really only took about an hour to cook and assemble which was a godsend because I have plans this afternoon so I could cook all the ingredients and assemble, then cover and let it set in the fridge so all I have to do is pop it in the oven until dinner. Thank you to all those before me who provided reviews, they were very helpful. NOTE: This was super rich. I couldn't even eat too much of it and my kids weren't keen on it at all. I am thankful to have tried it out, it was quite tasty but I probably won't make it again. It's just too heavy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made this recipe this afternoon.  My bf loved it! I think the following changes may have helped, because without them I could see how some reviewers would call this recipe too bland.   Chicken Prep: Melted 1/4 cup of butter in a stock pot, added onions and garlic, let them cook until nearly translucent. Added 4 whole breast of chicken seasoned with salt, pepper, and onion powder, cooked on each side for about 2 mins per side then filled the stock pot with boiling water.  Once chicken was cooked through I poured out the water and chilled the chicken in the fridge.  After chilled I shredded instead of cubing the chicken. 2nd change, I added the entire cup of parmesan to the sauce and an extra 1/2 c of mozzarella.  Sauce was not soupy at all. 3rd change; I took an 8oz pkg of softened cream cheese, whipped it, added the spinach to the cream cheese, seasoned with salt, pepper, a pinch of nutmeg. Then I added the ricotta to the cream cheese and spinach mixture.  I layered per the directions and cooked for 35-37 mins.  It was a huge hit!  Don't know if this will be a regular on the house hold menu since there are SOOO many steps involved.

Mom22GreatKids

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked the flavor of this recipe.  I was a tad worried when reading reviews that it would be bland.  But it turned out lovely.  A nice mellow taste, that wasn't overpowering.  I did follow the suggestion of another reviewer and mixed the chicken, ricotta, and spinach together.  It made for easier spreading.  Also, by total accident, I used all chicken broth (4c.) and left out the milk.  After I realized I did this, I was concerned it wouldn't turn out right.  However, I didn't notice anything different at the end.  Lastly, I only used half the spinach.  Two boxes probably would have been fine, but the kids don't like it too much, so I didn't want to push my luck!
I ended up layering it like this:  1 c. sauce, 3 noodles, 1/3 of the chicken mixture, 1/4 c. mozzarella.  I did three layers like this and then topped it off with the extra sauce and the remaining mozzarella on top. 
It's important to let it set for about 10 minutes before serving, that way the sauce thickens up and everything melds together well.  Overall, this was an excellent recipe.  It would be great to serve at a dinner party for guests.

text:
This recipe was delicious and so easy!! The only thing I did differently was that I only used 1 package of spinach, which was a perfect amount. Also, for the next time, I think I will shred the chicken meat instead of cutting it into cubes, since it everything else was so smooth that it was weird to bite into a chunk of chicken. Also, the next time I make this, I think that I will leave the seasonings out of the sauce (I thought it was a bit too much) and season the ricotta instead with about half of the amount of seasonings. Another thing I wish I did: usually when I make any type of pasta stuffed with ricotta, I will add an egg to the cheese and beat it up well--I think it holds it all together much better. This recipe didn't say to do that, so I didn't...and the ricotta just seemed to be falling out all over the place. Other than a few modifications I will make, I thought this recipe was delicious!! I will definitely make it again.

Display Name:
Chris
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A *very* tasty recipe but we had a few problems.  First, we used oven-ready lasagne noodles so we should have increased either the broth or milk to provide more moisture for cooking the noodles.  Because we didn't do this, the lasagne came out on the dry side.  (Some may prefer it this way, but I like my lasagne a bit on the "saucy" side.)  Next, we were in a rush so we didn't have time to properly thaw the spinach.  This resulted in "blobs" of spinach in some places, and no spinach in others.  Overall, though, we loved the results and, next time, will adjust the liquids and properly thaw the spinach for a better result.

UPDATE:  I made this a second time and it turned out just as tasty and not as dry as the first time.  Yummy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/44633.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe though time consuming but a few things I did to make it better: The sauce was really thick although I followed the recipe exactly, it didn't want to spread. I added additional stock to thin it out and it was perfect when done, not dry at all and held together well. You definitely need more than nine lasagna noodles, which is the reason I gave it only four stars. In order to fill the 9x13 pan, using 3 per layer there were gaps between the noodles. I ended up using 12 noodles which was inconvenient because I had only cooked nine. I used about three cups of chicken as two weren't enough for that big of a pan. I used fresh spinach instead of the frozen. I mixed the ricotta with an egg, parsley and parmesan which is how I do it for regular lasagna.

userID:
5488404
Display Name:
LoCoG2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/480547.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe. Like others suggested I used a layer with spinach, and added artichokes to my ricotta. Best lasagna ever! 

I sauteed my chicken with olive oil, onion and garlic salt and added mrs. dash (the yellow cap)

I mix the ricotta with artichokes, and garlic powder (any brand that says "marinated" and comes in a jar works well) make sure you really separate the pieces of artichoke or you'll get large chunks in a bite. Save the juice that the artichoke is marinating in for use in the spinach mixture. 

I used half mozzarella and half italian blend of cheeses ( I think there's asiago, provolone, and romano in that) along with parmesean and I make about 1.5X the amount of cheese sauce required and add 1/3 of it to 16 oz. of frozen spinach that I've thawed out in a separate pot. I add about 1/3-1/2 cup of marinade from the artichokes and about a tsp or 2 of chicken base. (for making chicken broth) I also add Mrs. Dash+Garlic/Onion salt to this mixture as well.

This makes 5 layers including noodles, (I layer sauce, noodles, ricotta, chicken, spinach) and it's a bit of extra work but the taste is WORTH it!
Review:

userID:
2468270
Display Name:
Lindsay Vereschagin Tripp
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2938722.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good, simple recipe although I did make a few changes to make a better fit in our house and based on past experiences with similar recipes. First I made 1 1/2 the amount of sauce and used more noodles, a full box. To the sauce in addition to the mozzarella I added about a cup of white wine and a good handful of shredded swiss cheese and fresh parmesan and a dash of nutmeg. I used way more garlic than called for. I shredded my chicken rather than dicing and mixed it into the ricotta mixture (ricotta, mozzarella, swiss, basil, oregano, garlic and pepper) to make one less thing to layer. Rather than using frozen spinach I used fresh broccoli cut into tiny florets that I blanched in the boiling pasta water for about 2 to 3 minuets till they JUST started to get tender, they will finish cooking when you bake the lasagne, before submerging in ice water to stop the cooking and preserve the bright green color. Next time I make this I will use the broccoli along with sauteed fresh spinach and sliced mushrooms. Zucchini would probably be good too. This is a great, easy and customizable recipe that will be added to my regular rotation.

country:
None
text:
Very good recipe. The only changes I made were soaking the noodles in hot tap water for about 30 minutes instead of boiling them and doubling the parmesan cheese(parmegano reggiano). I also used 1/2 cup heavy cream and one cup of milk. I accidently only used half the spinach and it was still plenty. I added an egg and some s/p garlic/onion powder to the ricotta and put the ricotta on two layers. I ended up using about 15 noodles in all and had to bake it a bit longer, a little over an hour. I let it sit for about an hour before cutting in to it and it came out beautiful. It all stayed together nicely and tasted delicious. Nice and creamy and oh so rich. One small piece will do it along side a salad with a tangy vinegrette. You need some acid to cut all the richness. Oh and I also used four garlic cloves and two onions. This recipe is definately a keeper!!

text:
These was delicious!!! I have made it twice already with excellent reviews from my family and in-laws. I added a splash of white wine to the sauce and extra garlic. I also sauteed some more garlic in oil and cooked cubed chicken seasoned w/some salt, pepper and onion powder. When the chicken was just about done cooking I added the spinach and sauteed for about a minute. This gave it a lot more flavor then just adding plain cooked chicken. I mixed the ricotta with an egg and some more seasonings (grated Parmesan, oregano, garlic powder, salt and pepper). I then layered sauce, noodles, ricotta mix and chicken/spinach mix then more sauce and so on.... I will definitely be making this again!  Even my very picky 2 year old (who does not eat meat or spinach) ate it!! The next time I make this I will double the sauce and use the extra to make pizza! yum!!!

This was very good, the only reason it did not get 5 stars from me was due to the following modifications I made or would make:  Chop the onion finely; eliminate the oregano and add 1-2 tbs. of fresh basil, one beaten egg, 1 package of spinach and a couple of dashes of nutmeg to the ricotta; use skim milk and low fat mozzarella; use no-cook lasagna pasta; eliminate the parsely; cover lasaagna for first 35 min, uncover let cook until bubbly; place under broiler for a few minutes to brown lightly

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Labor-intensive, but very, very good. I only cooked my noodles until flexible (about 3 minutes - they cooked the rest of the way in the oven) and used a pound of fresh spinach instead of the 2 pkgs of frozen. Washed the spinach in a collander and poured the noodle water over it to wilt, which meant one less pot to wash. Yay! A little salty for my taste, but I don't usually cook with much salt. Will probably make again someday.

Edit: I've made this several times now and upped my star count to 5. I crave this!! Easy to double, freezes beautifully. This last time I added 4 oz sliced mushrooms to the spinach layer. Not necessary, but soooo good!

text:
This lasagna is AMAZING with a few tweaks. I used a store bought rotisserie chicken - just enough chicken and lots of flavor! I used 1 bag of fresh spinach and sauteed it in olive oil with garlic, salt and pepper. It doesn't look like it would be enough, but we thought it was the perfect amount. For the sauce I added one green bell pepper and mushrooms.  I finely chopped the onion, pepper and mushrooms and sauteed them in olive oil with garlic salt. I used cottage cheese instead of the ricotta..personal preference. It ended up being full of flavor and so yummy! 

I did use regular lasagna and boiled it beforehand...and it still ended up taking over an hour to cook, just FYI!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1834587.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought I had rated this before, perhaps I have but  this is a good recipe. I make this once a month and it is a keeper at my house. A few tips I use for this are using oven ready lasagna noodles. making and chopping extra chicken when I am making something else with chicken during the month (you can always freeze and use when ready) . Also I freeze my white cheese so it breaks up when thawed without having to grate, It goes in the sauce anyway so why go to the bother of meticulously grating the cheese. I also buy frozen chopped spinach which I thaw and put in ice cube trays to refreeze in cubes and then a big zip lock freezer bag. I put spinach in just about everything. All you have to do is throw as many or little cubes as you need in your recipe... easy peasy. These short cuts make this dish pretty quick to make with results that look like you slaved all day. As for taste I always add a little half and half and a can of mushroom soup with a can of mushrooms and extra Basil. This is not to change the original recipe it's just personal preference after having made this as the original many times. This dish is supper tasty as well as attractive. Highly recommended!!!!!

text:
Before I say anything, I think this was the prettiest lasagna I've ever seen.  This was a good recipe, a nice twist on regular lasagna, but I still prefer the meat and red sauce.  I halved the recipe and put in an 8x8 pan (cookin for 2), I ended up needing about 1/2 c more broth to thin out the sauce, used cottage cheese instead of ricotta (my toddler doesn't like the texture), and used fresh spinach cooked down with T oil.  I think it just needs a little zing of pepper or something to make it memorable.

text:
Excellent recipe. I made the following changes: I don't boil the noodles because the sauce is moist enough to cook/soften them in the oven.. so skip the boil-the-noodles step and save yourself some time. Also in the interest of time.. I bought a rotisserie chicken already cooked, so it gave it a delicious roasted chicken flavor. I also used fresh spinach and fresh basil as well as fresh parsley on top. A sure winner!! Great job!!

This was very very good.  I subbed 1/2 cup dry white wine in the broth.  I used a 16 oz package of frozen spinach...plenty.  I think the basil was overpowering.  It would be better with just a teaspoon of italian seasoning.  Also, if you're going to put on the third layer of noodles you're going to need more than nine lasagna noodles, unless you use a small pan.  More like 12 noodles.  Overall, an excellent recipe.  Would be great with seafood and cajun seasoning instead of italian seasoning.

text:
Wow! The compliments flowed on Christmas! 
  I was looking for a non-red meat lasagna recipe, for those in our family who do not eat red meat. (Made a traditional lasagna as well.)This one sounded appealing, as it is did not call for canned chicken soup. I used two large cans of white chicken, which totaled two cups  Added a little more basil and oregano than recommended, as we love out Italian very spicy.  
  Made this up two days ahead, placed in freezer. Took out of freezer Christmas morn, and into a 250 degree oven about 3 hours prior to dinner, as it had not thawed thoroughly. Turned up the heat to 375 one hour prior and in less than 30 mins, lasagna was ready, complete with oohs and aahs from entire family.

text:
I read several reviews and made the following adjustments: I used 10 whole wheat lasagna noodles. They don't get mushy. I made 1&1/2 X sauce, 2 cloves garlic, 1/3-1/2 fresh basil, added 2 eggs to ricotta seasoned with 1/2 teas each of salt & pepper, used a bit more chicken, 2 large bags of fresh spinach sauteed in about a tbls. of olive oil (1 small clove of minced garlic), and I cut down on the amount of mozzarella and parmesan when assembling, since I had more sauce (therefore, more cheese). I made this for company and everyone had seconds (one man, even thirds). I will definitely make this again.

text:
I’m very careful about selecting recipes based on ingredients and reviews so this is my 1st unfavorable review which seems odd considering the number of comments and wonderful ingredients, but I understand now why so many rated this good after they had completely altered the recipe… as written doesn’t work. This dish is bland, a waste of time, and a waste of $.  I prepared according to directions plus seasoning the chicken as mentioned in the comments. 25 minutes prep time is completely unrealistic – it takes a lot longer to make this dish and it takes longer than 35 mins bake time to heat the dish in the middle.  There is absolutely no flavor and very little texture.  The ricotta cheese overpowers the chicken and spinach flavors.  Considering the amount of prep and time this took, I was expecting a fabulous dish and was extremely disappointed as was my family.

text:
The recipe calls for too much flour and too little chicken. I recommend that users start with 1/3 cup of flour and add more, if necessary, after adding the mozzrella and Parmesan. Also, 2 frozen packages of chopped spinach is too much, creating a crepe paper-like layer. I would use fresh spinach next time.

text:
Scrumptious. I did decrease the amount of sauce to 3/4 though and it was plenty, using 1/3 cup each of the butter and flour, 1 1/2 cups chicken broth and 1 cup 1% milk. Kept the same amount of cheeses.  But I used a 16 ounce bag of frozen spinach (on hand) and it was plenty for the recipe. Increased the chicken to 3 cups (to get rid of it.) I also layered the dish the same as for regular lasagna in equal layers to even out the flavors, spreading the chicken, ricotta and spinach evenly in 3 layers, rather than putting the ricotta, chicken and spinach in one layer each.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! This lasagna is delicious. My partner described it as 'the best dish I'd ever made' and devoured multiple servings of it.   I did follow the advice of other posters and added more cheese than the recipe called for. Specifically, I added an extra layer of mozzarella to the top of the lasagna and let it get all bubbly and gooey and delicious in the oven.  Also, DEFINITELY reduce the amount of spinach the recipe calls for. I put in less than half the spinach that was recommended, and it still bordered on too much.   Tips from other reviewers that I didn't follow, but probably would next time would include making a bit more sauce (the lasagna certainly wasn't dry, but the sauce was so delicious I want more!), and using fresh spinach rather than frozen (I prefer the taste and texture of fresh to frozen). Even without these modifications though, the lasagna was fantastic.  The quantity of basil and oregano called for in the recipe is perfect - it gives the lasagna a wonderful flavour without being overpowering.  I read some reviews that said this recipe was very time-consuming, but that's absolutely untrue. It took me less than 20 minutes to prepare! (not including baking time, of course)  Fantastic!

Yummy!  I made this for dinner tonight and even one of the pickiest kids ate it.  I added the spinach (I used fresh spinach) in with the cheese mixture as per another reviewer, but I could have better spent the extra 5 minutes to layer it like the recipe said.  Otherwise the taste was great and everyone gobbled it up.  I also boiled the chicken in chicken broth and shredded it (it takes a lot more time but I think it gives it a nice texture) then cooked the lasagna noodles in the chicken broth.  Full of flavour! Will definitely make again!

text:
This recipe was awesome. I made it for a dinner party of 8 people and it was just the right size. I did make a couple of adjustments however. I only used one box of frozen spinach instead of two and I mixed the ricotta and spinach together. Also I added one container of fresh sliced mushrooms to the sauce when I added the onions and garlic to the pan. I also added 4 cloves of garlic instead of one. I sauteed the diced chicken breasts in olive oil, cajun seasoning, salt, pepper, and garlic powder to give it some flavor. Overall it was great- everyone at the dinner party asked me for the recipe. I will definitely make this one again. I think 2 boxes of spicach would have been way too much.

text:
Normally I don't write reviews but I think this dish deserved an applause. I did make a few changes based on ingredients I had on hand and the amount of time I had to cook (the moms and or dads out there with children under 1 can relate with me). Changes: red onion instead of white, rotisserie chicken instead of breast (I can get the chicken already cooked from the grocery store and the left overs I used for soup!), substituted 1 cup of mozzarella with 1 cup of pepper jack cheese; to give the dish a little spice. I also added a bit of EasiSpice all purpose seasoning and thyme. All in all this dish  is a new favorite.

userID:
2414866
Display Name:
ManassasMa
isPro:
False
followersCount:
27
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
127
favoritesCount:
148
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This SAUCE for this recipe is wonderful (hence, the 5 star rating); I use it often for various pasta preparations (for example, when I make Ravioli, Rigatoni, or Fettucine). I usually add just a dash of Nutmeg to it -- just to make it a tad more "interesting". For my Vegetable Lasagnas, I use "regular" Lasagna (not pre-cooked) noodles (remember to transfer them to a pot or bowl of cold water once you drain them -- they stick to one another if you don't), a 4-Italian Cheese blend, and I make 1/3rd more Sauce than this recipe calls for. I use fresh Spinach and I include sliced (with a vegetable peeler, then chopped into 3 parts) Carrots and sliced (ditto) Zucchini. Sometimes I also include Mushrooms, sometimes I don't; sometimes I include Chicken (and when I do, sometimes I use pre-cooked boneless thighs instead of breasts and sometimes I use leftovers from a whole roasted chicken), but sometimes I don't. I'm never particular about how I layer (except for the Sauce); I pretty much mix all of my "filling" ingredients together in one large bowl and then I proceed as follows:   (a) Sauce, Noodles, Filling, (b) Noodles, Filling, Sauce, (c) Noodles, Sauce, CHEESE. I let it sit for about 10 minutes (giving the ingredients a chance to "get used to one another"), and then I bake it, covered with aluminum foil, for 30-40 minutes at 350 F. After the 30-40 minutes, I remove the foil and bake for another 10-15 minutes. I let it "rest" for at least 20 minutes before attempting to slice.

text:
I have done this recipe many, many times.  It is always a hit @ Pot lucks & I get many requests to bring to showers, etc.   I follow this recipe to a tee.   
The only bone I have to pick w this recipe is the Prep time.  I DOESNOT take only 25 mins for prep.  ( The video  for this recipe takes 25 mins...lol).  It realistically times out to more like 1 hr for prep time.   
By the time you  boil the noodles, drain them & make your white cheese sauce & brown & cook your chicken & assemble the lasagna...its definetly a 1 hr prep time.  
So be prepared for that prep time.   Is it worth it?   YES....all the compliments are great!!

userID:
849226
Display Name:
Shannon
isPro:
False
followersCount:
18
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
303
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was excited to try this, as I'm not much of a red sauce lasagna fan, however, this wasn't quite as good as I was expecting. As written, I would've imagined a very bland outcome, so I decided beforehand to take the following liberties with this recipe in order to spruce up the flavor: I used my crockpot to cook the chicken (I used a 1lb pkg of boneless, skinless thighs) that I shredded and seasoned to taste. I also used a 10 oz bag of fresh baby spinach, de-stemmed and finely chopped (I wouldn't dream of using frozen or canned spinach, blech!) I used a 15 oz container of part-skim ricotta and added freshly ground pepper, salt, garlic/onion powders and basil. I didn't add an egg to the ricotta mixture, though I would in the future. I seasoned the sauce to taste as well, omitting the oregano (don't care for it) and doubling the basil. I combined the chicken, ricotta and spinach to make layering easier. I also chopped up a roma tomato and added some real bacon bits to the layers. I used oven-ready noodles and baked an hour to ensure it was fully cooked. I loosely covered my lasagna with foil all but the last 10 minutes and broiled the last two minutes to get a good, light browning on the top. I was expecting more sauce, however, that's a personal preference and an easy fix for next time with some tweaking. I do like the idea of a white sauce lasagna, so I'll attempt this one again.

country:
None
text:
Oh my!  This is fantastic!  I changed a few things based on personal taste.  I used uncooked lasagna noodles and they cooked perfectly in the sauce.  I added about 4 cloves of garlic and substitued Sargento's 6-cheese Italian blend for the mozzarella.  I used 1 9 oz bag of fresh spinach instead of frozen.  I also used fresh basil instead of dried...the flavor is so much better.  I also eliminated the oregano...just my personal preference.  Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly as far as the the quantities and layering and it turned out perfectly!  I never cook the noodles in advance for any lasagna recipe.  I personally think by precooking and then baking, the noodles end up being overcooked and a little on the mushy side.  Besides, by not cooking, it saves time as well!  Thank you so much for posting this recipe...it will go in with my favorites!

RESTAURANT QUALITY!!! This was DELICIOUS!! I cut the recipe in half so I used an 8x8 instead.  Like another reviewer, I accidentally added all of the mozzarella to the sauce mixture but it turned out fine!  I did add a little extra chicken broth because I used no boil noodles. I made this again and it turned out even better using the regular noodles!  I just boiled them first while cooking the chicken.  I added some extra mozzarella in between one of the layers.  YUM!  I've shared this recipe with friends who have loved it also!  I can't wait to make the sauce and use it in/on other things.

text:
This part of the recipe is KILLER if you set it aside then use it to pour over fetucchini noodles and chicken. The best!   **Melt the butter in a large saucepan over medium heat. Cook the onion and garlic in the butter until tender, stirring frequently. Stir in the flour and salt, and simmer until bubbly. Mix in the broth and milk, and boil, stirring constantly, for 1 minute. Stir in 2 cups mozzarella cheese and 1/4 cup Parmesan cheese. Season with the basil, oregano, and ground black pepper. Remove from heat, and set aside.

text:
I liked this, but I found it to be a little bland.  As my boyfriend described it, it was like macaroni and cheese with chicken.  We both expected a little more from this dish; I would add more garlic and herbs for flavor.  I also used one package of ground chicken instead of shredded chicken; after it was cooked I had about 2 1/3 cups, a little extra but I used it in the lasagna.  I got every dish in my kitchen dirty trying to make this, haha! I would make this again but it won't be something I regularly make; I'll probably use it as a substitute for regular lasagna maybe once every year or two, as my boyfriend suggested. A helpful suggestion I read was to mince the onions really fine; I did, and the texture was much nicer than if I had decided to "chop" the onions.  Also, I had to let the dish sit for around 20 minutes to thicken before serving.

text:
This is an excellent recipe I have been making for some time now.  I use no-cook noodles to save time.  To keep from drying out, I make extra sauce (add an extra tablespoon of flour or so and adjust broth/milk/cheese).  Also, I prefer to shred the chicken which gives this recipe really great texture. This is a definite keeper in our house.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was pretty good. I made one for my family and then the next day, made it for a friend who just had a baby, with a few improvements. First, I used the whole package of lasagna noodles to make 3 layers. Second, I disregarded the original assembly instructions and layered like this: sauce, noodles, ricotta, chicken, spinach, cheese...repeat. Also, the first attempt was a little dry in places, so I made a little more of the white sauce and mixed it in with the ricotta to add moisture. I also used one 16-oz package of frozen spinach for 2 lasagnas. Good recipe, will make again!

text:
I always have frozen, roasted chicken my freezer.Great to defrost and toss in a salad-quesadilla, this lasagna. So mine came together quickly.  Could also use a roasted chicken from the deli to save time.  Excellent recipe.  Agree-needs more garlic.  I used three cloves.  I did one cup of milk and one half cup of 1/2 and 1/2.  Also, can definitely mix the washed and dried spinach with the chicken and add to the sauce.  Kind of eliminates the layering which isn't noticeable and saves time, too.  Great recipe, a sure keeper!

For me, this wasn't that great. This COULD be turned into something really good to suit one's personal tastes. However, as is, it's really heavy. The sauce has way too much flour and there is too much cheese. The directions should actually advise one to cook the flour until it's golden brown, much like a rue. Otherwise, it tastes floury. Overall, this is pretty bland and rich (in a bad way).

text:
I made this the other day and it turned out great.  The changes I made to it:

I made the white sauce with milk only, so it was quite a bit thicker than the printed recipe's version.  I like lasagna to hold together when it's removed from the pan.

I added sauteed mushrooms along with the spinach to bump up the vegetables.

I used a store-bought rotisserie chicken and cut the breast met up into much smaller pieces than the printed recipe recommends.  I wanted every bite of the lasagna to have chicken.

I cut the entire recipe in half.  I'm a single guy and recipes meant for 6-8 people are way too large, even if I am freezing left-overs.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7586829.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious lasagna but it is really heavy so probably not something you want to make too often.
I made a few changes-
I seasoned the chicken with some garlic, paprika, salt, black pepper and all spice to give it some more flavour. 
I used no boil lasagna so I did take the suggestion to add an extra 1/2 cup of milk ( also added 1/2 cup of whipping cream)to the bechamel sauce and it was not too saucy at all! I also added 1/2 cup more parmesan and a little nutmeg for flavour. 
I sautéed onions, mushrooms and spinach with olive oil and garlic and added that together as a layer instead of the plain frozen spinach. It was very delicious!
I will definitely be making this many more times in the future.

ustacks

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6151673.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out delicious on my first attempt! I took a chance that it would be good and doubled most ingredients in the recipe to make 2 9×13 pans. I'm so happy I did! I boiled my chicken breast with bay leaves and bouillon cubes for flavor. Then made a separate chix broth with bouillon cubes bay leaves and the spices. I also sautéd my spinach with garlic & olive oil then removed and sauted the onions and garlic in more olive oil in the same pan. I also used more cheese and skim milk and added some fresh basil to my spinach which I mixed with the ricotta. I also added an egg to the ricotta mix which is what I do for standard lasagna.  I baked both trays covered in foil for 1hr then removed it and let them cook 15 min more. Then let it sit for 20min before cutting.
This was so tasty and satisfying. Great combination of flavors! I will absolutely make this again. Thank you Lisa!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/835158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really like this!  Changes made were: I used no-boil noodles, so added an extra 3/4 c. of chicken broth and about an extra half cup of milk to accommodate the liquid for the noodles.  I used the leftover meat from a rotisserie chicken (so it was fairly well seasoned to begin with), and boosted the garlic to 4 cloves.  I added 2 eggs to the ricotta, as I always do with lasagne, and mixed in the thawed spinach, the mozzarella and the parmesan just to make the layering easier.  Next time I will definitely use fresh spinach and saute it first, but didn't have any on hand this time.  I followed the directions from the back of the lasagne noodle box for baking - 375 degrees, covered with foil, for about 55 minutes, followed by 5 minutes uncovered, and then 15 minutes stand time before cutting.  Very rich meal, so half of it is going in the freezer!  One other thing:  This OVERFILLS a 13 x 9 glass baking dish, so either find something deeper or be prepared with foil on the bottom of the oven!!!!!

userID:
3318163
Display Name:
Miss Megan
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

2
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good, could be a 5 star with several changes though:
1. The chicken turned out overcooked. I recommend slightly under cooking it before baking, or shredding the chicken. I cooked the chicken in a pan with basil, garlic and oregano to avoid the bland tastes others posted about.
2. I thought that the spinach had a weird texture (prob shouldn't of used frozen). Next time I will put the spinach and artichokes *added due to preference* in a blender to puree, then add to the cheese sauce.
3. Since I had no ricotta or cottage cheese (of course), I used feta mixed with cream cheese and a tad of sour cream and YUM! Makes it a little more creamy than ricotta.
With these changes it is FABULOUS! I made mine ahead of time, then refrigerated a few hours while I went to class, turned out great. It also makes a ton and since there's just two of us in my house we had mass amounts of leftovers. So I dipped them in egg and breadcrumbs and fried til crispy, served with ranch and marinara and SO GOOD! Def recommend that :)

I actually had to sop up oil/butter that pooled on the top during baking.  It was also very salty...the day after the salt was not as noticable, but I would definitely omit the salt next time. Other than that, it was tasty!

text:
uhh, YUM.  This was so good, everyone in the family loved it.  Minor changes - I used homemade lasagna noodles, steamed fresh spinach, and I added pureed zucchini and broccoli.  Didn't have any ricotta so I used cottage cheese.  I mixed the spinach, zucchini and broccoli with the cottage cheese to make layering easier.  I chose not to cook my noodles ahead of time so I added 1/2 c of water to the sauce, but they didn't cook that great in the white sauce (I've had great success not cooking them ahead of time for traditional red sauce lasagna).  Next time I'll cook them ahead of time for sure!  Will be making this again.

text:
This is one of my favorite lasagnas. I usually buy bone-in chicken and put it in the slow cooker, which yields both the chicken broth and the cooked chicken. I also use whole wheat lasagna noodles (there are so many flavors you can't taste the difference). Finally, I prefer using fresh spinach instead of frozen.

userID:

Display Name:
Megan Gillott Williams
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2352878.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great recipe...no need for the salt if you use boulion cubes for the broth like I did. And I actually added in 4 cups of broth because the sauce seemed rather thick without it. I cooked some carrots in the broth with the diced chicken and sauted some mushrooms in with the garlic and onions, as well (used 2 tsp minced garlic.) I did not add the cheese in the sauce- I always just sprinkle in the cheese when layering. I also mixed the spinach and ricotta together into its own mixture and spread in between each layer. You do not need quite as much cheese as this recipe calls for...I probably used about 3 cups total...used a shredded italian blend rather than the mozerella and parmesan. Will definitely make this again.

Based on other reviewers, I decided to add a bit more salt as well as an extra clove of garlic.  I also sauted chicken and wilted fresh spinach in the leftover juices instead of using frozen.  I didn't add as much spinach as the original recipe called for.  Came out great, and very glad I decided to tweak it a bit to my taste or it would have been too bland.  Great, great recipe when adding personal touches.  My kids, my husband as well as myself enjoyed this different take on lasagna.

text:
Cut butter by less than half.  Used minced onion and garlic powder.  Omit salt.  (Would think about using sauce with spinach over pasta noodles, as with ricotta it was really rich.)  To layer, made a mix of chx, ricotta, spinach, and 1/2 c parmesan, then did noodles, sauce, then chx/cheese mix.  Next time would maybe add white wine as other reviewers mentioned.  I used only 10 oz spinach--was enough.
ETA:  Made this with just the sauce for pasta and it was good.  A little thick, so I may add some extra milk at the end next time.

text:
this is a wonderful recipe!  i did make a couple of minor changes for time sake.  i mixed the ricotta cheese, spinach and added some chopped portobella mushrooms.  also, used the no-boil lasagna noodles (just added about a half cup more milk to the sauce mix so it didn't turn out dry) covered it with foil and baked it at 375 for 50 min covered and about 10 uncovered for the cheese to brown.  it was a HUGE hit with the hubby and kids!

Very good recipe. I tweaked it a little as suggested by other reviewers by adding a little more garlic to cheese mixture. I seasoned then slow baked my chicken covered in the oven so it fell off the bone and used the broth from it. Came out great and got me thinking what a good pizza these ingredients would make.

text:
I made a few changes.  I added 1/2 c asiago cheese to the ricotta (prob didnt need it).  Also, the most important change was to add the spinach to the cheese sauce.  The sauce was really thick, so I added a little extra milk.  The spinach in the sauce made it look better and was one less layer.  My layers were:  cheese & spinach sauce, noodles,  chicken, noodles, ricotta layer, 2 c mozzarella w 1/2 c parmesan, then noodles, sauce, more chicken, noodles, sauce, 1/2 c parmesan and parsley.  Alot of layers.  Kids liked it.

text:
This really is as wonderful as reviewed!! I actually thought the sauce was good enough to go directly onto pasta with grilled chicken and may just do so! I did omit the spinach as we do not care for it and it set up just as well without, something I was worried about. To be warned, it is most certainly rich but serving a salad on the side helps with that. Having made many cheese sauces I can say that this one is not nearly as fattening by using he broth and milk instead of cream, something I may consider trying with my other recipes, such as baked mac & cheese.

Made this tonight with a few changes due to what I had on hand. Used 12 noodles, shredded chicken that I had in the freezer from a rotiserie chicken, one package of frozen spinach, added sauted mushrooms and a bit of chopped garlic. Didn't change anything on the sauce and it had great flavor. Was not bland at all. Had guests and we all loved it. Was a bit of work but using the chicken I had made it faster. Thanks!

Very good! I served this for a group last night and everyone really like it. I followed the recommendations of reviewers; added white wine to the sauce, mixed the chicken/ricotta/spinach together, didnt add as much spinach as orignal recipe (only one pack), added more garlic, chopped onion super fine, added more cheese, etc. Many of you may hate me but I still thought it was kind of bland- still 4 star quality! BUT I warmed some marinara sauce in a pan and poured that over each slice before serving and I wouldnt do it any other way! Soo good with some added flavor!!

text:
This was simply delicious. The sauce was so good, I put some of it on a piece of bread and ate it like that! I wanted to take a bath in it, it was THAT good. The only thing I might try and "doctor" a bit is the ricotta and chicken layer..it seemed a bit bland in comparison to the rest of the layers...but all in all...cheesy, gooey, deep-down-satisfying meal. I am making it again in a couple of days at my mother in law's house because I think it will impress!  On a side note, I prepared this in the morning, while both of my kids were sleeping or busy, giving me time to myself, and put it in the fridge until the evening...it made dinner time a snap and I was able to relax and enjoy my family while it was cooking. I will do that again for SURE!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5152062.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, I changed a couple of things, mainly the assembly of the sauce and cooking of the chicken.  I also don't rinse my noodles, instead I use a little bit of olive oil to keep them from sticking to each other. For the sauce, I partially cooked the cubed chicken with 1 tablespoon of olive oil, then added onions and a half of a head of garlic(crushed), salt, pepper, basil, oregano to finish cooking.  Added the butter, melted, then added 1 1/2 C chicken stock and 1/2 c. white wine to simmer, added the 1 1/2 cups of milk to simmer, stirring often.  I mixed the flour into the mozzarella and parmesan (reggiano of course) , then added it to the simmering mixture on the stove by handfuls stirring constantly.  I assembled the whole concoction as directed, adding black olives with the ricotta cheese and scooping the chicken out of the sauce when needed.  And using fresh spinach (rinsed and wilted on the stove beforehand)  Put it over a cookiesheet for spillage then baked it as directed.   This was delicious!

text:
Made this for New Year's Eve. Fantastic recipe! So excited to find a chicken lasagna that doesn't call for "cream of whatever". Used fresh spinach instead of frozen (bad childhood memories). Also, I had extra rotisserie chicken meat in the freezer, so I used that. Otherwise followed exactly. I didn't find it bland at all, and I'm a salt/pepper-aholic. Be sure to use plain chicken stock instead of low sodium and a good aged parm and blandness won't be a problem. TRY THIS RECIPE! Great for special events when calories aren't a big issue!

text:
This was very good...I made it today, I used chicken breast which I baked earlier with a little salt, pepper, and a bit of lemon juice, it was very moist, and the broth it made was very good, so I used that broth for my sauce...I also used fresh spinach, which I threw in with my onions & garlic when they were almost done....hubby even threw in some chopped cilantro coz we didn't have fresh parsley...I also used cottage cheese instead of ricotta coz that's all I had on hand, but I added an egg, parmesan cheese and a bit of the cilantro in....the sauce was soooo rich & creamy, very decadent, hubby loved it, in fact he was dipping a few pieces of chicken in the sauce as I was putting it together...I am SOOO glad  Ifound &  tried this recipe instead of some of the others on the site, it took a bit longer, but I didn't want an alfredo sauce w/either cream of chicken or mushroom soup...very rich & fattening, but very good, and worth all the effort...we served it w/a nice salad and garlic bread...will be making again for special occasions...

text:
This recipe is absolutely fantastic!!!  I used oven-ready lasagna, added an egg and a little salt to the ricotta mixture, and used one 14 oz. pkg. spinach instead of 2 10 oz. pkgs.  I layered exactly as shown, but baked covered for 40 min., then uncovered for another 10 min.  Then let rest for about 10 min. before serving.  It came out perfect!!  The sauce was to die for!  I used skim milk and it was still plenty rich and creamy.  Will definitely make this one again!!

text:
Yum! you don't have to boil the lasagna noodles, just leave them sitting in super hot water while you prepare everything else and by the time you need them, they are nice and tender :) I added a beaten egg, some mozzerella and parmesan cheese to the ricotta to give it more of a lasagna taste. i only added one package of spinach and felt like even that was a bit much. wasn't too fond of the spinach so maybe next time i'll add something like broccoli or maybe just the plain chicken. overall though, it was great. my only complaint is that i had a ton of dishes to wash afterwards :)

text:
I am rating this recipe for the idea of a white cheese chicken lasagne.  I will admit that I did not follow the recipe, but took a couple of shortcuts.  First, I bought rotissierie chickens and used the chicken from those.  Second, I purchased Ragu alfredo sauce (3 jars) and used that rather than make my own white sauce.  And finally, I forgot to buy ricotta so I just used additional mozzerella and my family loved it.  I will use this as a regular rotation item in my menu.  Thanks for the recipe.  Oooohhh, one more thing, I did use two boxes of chopped spinach and thought it was perfect.

I make Chicken Alfredo all the time and I needed a little change. This was VERY good. I used a 5 oz pkg of fresh spinach, which I had sautéed in about 1/4 cup of water until wilted. I might use 10 oz next time even though I feel 5 was just fine for me. Cubed two skinless chicken breasts and sautéed in same pan I used for spinach with 2 TBPS butter, minced garlic, and 2 tsp Italian Seasoning. I didn't add the oregano and basil.. only Italian Seasoning.

text:
Wonderful recipe.  Quite rich, so make for a treat.  I halved the recipe, served 5 well.  I used less butter, it's already rich enough with all the cheese - used 2 TB for this size.  Use 5 noodles if so, bake in an 8x8 pan.  I used more garlic, 2 TB pesto rather than the oregano basil and parsely, added more spinach and chicken, and added one egg to the ricotta.  Turned out amazing.  For those who like mushrooms they'd also be good added.  Also, I used ground chicken which worked very well.

text:
This lasagna is absolutely delicious! I followed some tips from other people who reviewed the recipe and cut the spinach down to one box and it was just the right amount for our taste. I sauteed the chicken in olive oil, salt, pepper, and italian seasoning to give it a little zing, and it was a good compliment to the dish. I also substituted the basil and oregano for italian seasoning, and the sauce tied in well with the chicken. I also added a beaten egg in with my ricotta to help it hold up better. The only thing I will do differently next time, is mix the spinach with the ricotta cheese to make it blend better. This recipe is definitely worth the work involved in preparing it, and is a good go-to dish when you need to impress company. :)

text:
I was a bit sceptical seeing how I've never made a chicken lasagna before and it was my turn to cook a Saturday night dinner for the family, but turns out there was nothing to worry about. 

I took some of the tips from the other reviews - use fresh spinach and cut the stems off and cook it in a pan with oil until bright green; blend the chicken, ricotta and spinach together for easier layering; and use no bake noodles and let them cook with the lasagna. 

My family loved it and it turned out so well they thought that I've cooked it many times before! Highly reccomend!

I was so excited about trying this recipe after I read all the reviews! It sounded amazing! I followed the recipe to a T except for 2 things...I add extra garlic and I only added the one package of Spinach. It really didn't have that much flavor it was kind of bland...all I could taste was the basil and oregano, way to much in my opinion the flavor was overpowering! I don't know why everyone has given this such great reviews, I couldn't even eat all of my first helping. I deffinetly will not be makeing this again. I think if you cut back on the herbs it might be better.

text:
OMG!!!!!OMG!!!!!OMG!!!! I have to give this recipe a 5 but I have to admit that I had to do a lot of reading to pull that off.  After reading that it turned out bland, Iknew I had to add extra seasoning to it.  I used italian seasoning instead of the individual seasonings called for in the recipe.  I also followed another persons suggestion to marinate the chicken in italian dressing before cooking.  I also added more italian seasoning to my chicken breast while cooking.  This made a major difference with flavor.  I  added a teaspoon of nutmeg, reduced the amount of spinach(which I also seasoned) added  1/2 cup more of milk and used 2cups mozzarella and 2 cups mild cheddar (what I had available) and crumbled 4 slices of turkey bacon.  Let me tell you, I am so proud of the way this recipe turned out, I could kiss myself!  The Hubby loved it and told me that it was better than the one he eats at his favorite italian rest. and I agree.

text:
This was very good.   The only change I made was adding a dash of nutmeg to the cheese sauce to make it more of an authentic white sauce flavor.  I didn't have just the basil or oregano so I used the italian blend, it's the same thing.  NOTE about the Chicken.  Canned chicken will drastically change the flavor.  If you like the taste of canned chicken you will love it all, if you don't like canned chicken you will taste it most definatley.  I boiled down fresh chicken, and chopped it very fine... It was perfect.  Also, for the riccota cheese, I add some 1/4 cup parm cheese to it and one egg to it.. mix it up and it is fluffier when baked  and much easier to spread. This was a definate do over recipe and I rateit as easy to prepare.  I am going to pre freeze a pan before baking next time for emergencies and quick fixes.

text:
I made this for the second time last night and it was even better than the first time! Both my boyfriend and I loved it!!!! I used more chicken than called for, used a lot more garlic, and added an extra layer of noodles and therefore more cheese. This is a great recipe, the leftovers are even better than the first night! This is a great recipe to make at the beginning of the week so you can eat the leftovers for lunch during the week. This is a great recipe to serve to guests, as everyone who has tried it has said they LOVED it! However, I would plan for more time than they mentioned; the cook time is correct, but the prep time took me a lot longer. This could be due to the fact that I don't think they add cooking the chicken but plan for more time or else you might be eating dinner at 8pm like me. :) Anyway, this deserves all five stars!

text:
I made this for company and they each had 4th helpings!  This was SO good!  Instead of boiling the lasagna noodles, I laid them in a 13x9 and poured boiling water on them to submerge them.  They cooked that way while I put everything else together.  I used chicken bouillon cubes mixed in hot water rather than chicken broth (didn't have any).  The layers were confusing as described, so I did the sauce layer on bottom, then noodles, ricotta, mozzarrella, chicken, spinach, sauce...then repeat.  I sprinkled spinach and parm & mozzarrella on the top of the dish to give it a more colorful look.  FABULOUS!  I will definitely make this again!!!

Oh my Gosh!  Fantastic!!  Even my husband who doesn't like white sauce or spinach ate seconds. Oh so yummy!  I only made some minor changes because of what I had on hand. 1. Added 3 extra cloves garlic 2. Used fresh basil & oregano from my garden 3. My husband hates ricotta so I used diced Colby/jack cheese 4. Cooked lightly covered with foil, sprayed with oil. Uncovered last 10 minutes THEN topped with last of fresh shredded parmasean cheese. Leftovers were great the next day too!I made a big batch and froze a couple of single servings for later. I defrosted and warmed. It was just as fantastic. Update:  Made this for friends, forgetting I had it and loved it in the past.  Everyone raved.  I changed it slightly due to other reviewers.  I added cooked bacon (some to the inside and some on top) I cut the spinach a bit.  It needs to be cooked way longer than it said to make it really yummy (which is why it's better the next day.)

text:
I liked this dish a lot.  My wife, not being a white sauce fan, wasn't quite as happy with it.  I wanted the chicken to have some flavor, so I pounded some chicken breasts to a uniform thickness, sprinkled them with salt and pepper, drizzled them with olive oil, and grilled them just until cooked.  I used a pound and a half of chicken and thought that was too little.  Next time, I'll use almost 3 pounds of chicken for a 9x13 pan.  Lastly, I thought the sauce was an awful lot of work, thanks to how long I had to keep stirring before the broth and milk heated all the way up to boiling.  Next time, I'll preheat them most of the way in the microwave.

This recipe is BASICALLY good, however, flour/milk do not exactly have much flavour even when combined with chicken broth was rather bland. text:
My family enjoyed this recipe.  I made some changes, partly due to our personal preferences and partly to add more flavor.  With my changes, my family definitely gave this a 5.  I first sauteed the chopped chicken breast in a little olive oil and Montreal chicken seasoning.  Instead of chopped spinach, I used chopped broccoli since I had it.  I also added two chopped carrots that I precooked a bit in the microwave to soften them.  I did use the whole 2 cups of ricotta cheese, but next time I would use less.  It seemed to make a very heavy layer.  I kept the cheese sauce recipe exactly as it was.  It was quite rich, but very well received.  Definitely a recipe I would make again- when I have the time, because it was quite time consuming.

text:
Everybody LOVED this dish!!  It was a bit time consuming to make, because I boiled and shredded the chicken by hand, and also used fresh spinach cooked in olive oil.  I also layered it the way a regular lasagna is layered, this was excellent!  (Round 2)  This time I added an extra clove of garlic, and cut up chicken breasts to saute in a skillet.  I used fresh baby spinach, sauted in a little olive oil in a skillet, then threw in some chopped mushrooms.  I only used one bag of spinach, should have used 2.  What starts out as one big bag, cooks down to only a handful.  Next time I think I will also cut down on the mozzarella.  The lasagna was really good, but the mozzarella cheesiness was a little much for us.  Overall a great dish. (Round 3) Ok. I got a request for this recipe for a group lunch, so I made it again.  I am giving this another star, because I really really liked it this time better than the other times I made it.  I threw the chicken breasts into my George Foreman grill, I used about 14 oz of chopped spinach (frozen, thawed), I added fresh mushrooms to the layers, and I think I did everything else as its written, except for adding some garlic. I also put it together the night before the lunch and it sat in the fridge overnight, maybe that's what did it?  I have no idea, but this lasagna turned out very very yummy.  Served with a crisp mixed salad.

text:
This is a very good dish. Loads of flavor and cheese. This was my first time making my own sauce and it came out great. The only problem I had was with the layering and chicken cubes. I would say shred the chicken and lightly salt & pepper it. The chicken and ricotta layer was a sort of jarring absence of flavor and weird texture the way it is set in the current recipe. Everything else was really good and now that I know to make sure the sauce is properly touching the chicken with every bite, it's much better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so cheesy...in the best way possible! My family really liked this. Being Italian though I have a few minor changes that literally make this go from a work of art to a freaking masterpiece! Tips: 1. Cook an entire box of lasagna noodles. 2. One package of frozen spinach is more than enough 3. Take the ricotta and mix an egg in it with salt, pepper, AND the spinach. 4. Layer as follows: sauce, lasagna noodles, ricotta, sauce, and cheese - repeat: lasagna noodles, ricotta, sauce, and cheese. After all done layering, cover the lasagna with foil and cook for 40 minutes, then take the foil off and cook for another 10 minutes or until the cheese is bubbly and brown. (The only other thing that would make this that much more is make it the night before and let it sit in the fridge overnight. ) Poof it's amazeballs!

None
text:
Excellent when you want something creamy and succulent. I added juice of half a lemon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg to the white sauce.   When white sauce was done I threw like 10 oz Spinach in there on low heat, and also threw the chicken in, then threw some lemon pepper seasoning in there. It became a thick chunky mixture when altogether. So I layered the baking dish with the pasta and chicken sauce and mozzarella, but then I made 1 cup more white sauce in the just used pan to drizzle over baking dish to make it more saucy. Topped with bits of Spinach and shredded parmesan and Let it bake for 35 min, then a 2 or 3 min broil to get a golden brown crust and voila. Angels sang when I had the first bite.

text:
It was good, I made a few changes:
• used Monterey Jack instead of Parmesan because that's what I had on hand
• sauteed mushrooms and used fresh spinach
• extra extra extra garlic!
• I put an egg, salt and some parsley in my ricotta!
 
I added the mushroom and spinach to the white sauce and then threw the chicken in there, I wish I would have just added the chicken seperately because it was hard to see how evenly it was dispersed throughout the casserole dish.

Mine came out pretty tastey but fairly sloppy, wasn't the typical lasagna consistency. I had to scoop, not Slice... 

I may try adding some more salt, chicken and perhaps bacon or a breadcrumb topping to add some texture next time! 

Overall, good flavors-very creamy.

text:
made this for the first time for a dinner party last night. it was an absolute hit. it was relatively easy to make, made it a few hours ahead of time and then put in fridge. only changes i made were to add more garlic to the onion and butter, add wine to the roux mix and more cheese to the layering of the lasagna.  mixed one package of spinach with the chicken and ricotta and then used that to layer.used  barilla no boil noodles which worked great. covered with foil for 40 minutes and then uncovered for 20 minutes to finish cooking. just a great meal. elegant and delicious!

text:
Great recipe base!  Even my picky eaters gobbled this up.  I always doctor everything tho.  I lightly cooked some asparagus and mushrooms together to add to the ricotta cheese and spinach mix, which I doubled the amount of spinach.  I also added just a touch of white wine to the sauce mix.  Instead of chicken chunks, I used 2 pounds of ground chicken, there was a much more even spread.  I also used some of my fresh herbs from the garden, which isn't always an option.  Will definitely make this again, but with my own touch.

I was excited to find this recipe after having tried a white lasagna for the first time at a party.  It wasn't quite as good (the one I had tried had been professionally made), but it came pretty close.  I did find it to be a bit bland on day #1, but the leftovers on day #2 were fabulous as there had been time for the flavours to blend together.  Next time I"ll add more seasoning.  Also, this would be just as great without the chicken, I imagine!

***UPDATE***  I made this without the chicken, as per my original review above.  Turned out just great.  Served with quinoa and spinach stuffed tomatoes, so we got our protein from the quinoa.  Just excellent, I won't bother with the chicken next time!

text:
As is, the recipe is good.  A few adjustments made it great.  First, I hate Ricotta cheese.  I can't stand the texture of it.  I used Cottage cheese and added Asiago for extra flavor.  I wish when people write a recipe using fresh garlic, instead of saying "1 clove", since every clove is a different size, they'd say "a teaspoon or tablespoon".  I used about a heaping teaspoon, but wish I'd added more.  I also added some diced sun dried tomatoes to the sauce at the last minute.  I also sautéed about a cup of dice portabella mushrooms and mixed them with the spinach.  Oh, I took another reviews idea and only used milk instead of chicken broth.  It made the sauce thick but really good.

I tried this recipe for a family birthday lunch and everyone loved it! It has more cheese in it than almost any recipe I've ever made, but the taste is wonderful. text:
I wish we could give half stars, I would give this recipe 3.5 stars as is. Something is off with the seasonings. Hubby declared it 'different' - I made homemade lasagna noodles for mine (the noodles were great) - used 3 cloves of garlic instead of one (we love garlic), sautéed 1 pound of fresh spinach and an extra splash of milk since my sauce got almost too thick to spread. I don't know if its the oregano that gave it a funky taste for us or the Basil. I'm normally a huge fan of Basil so I'm guessing it may have just been too much oregano. Might try it again when I have the time, but will definitely adjust the seasonings.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe.  Have made it several times.  The only thing I did was to season the chicken breasts before cooking them.  It's important to make one layer of spinach and the next layer of chicken.  They will keep their individual tastes/flavors that way.  Don't follow advice of others and mix it all together (really).  A couple of times, I substituted broccoli cuts for the spinach and it was good.  A lot of work . . . but so well worth it.  ALSO - use the lasagna noodles that you cook.  So much better than the non-cook.

text:
2nd try- I browned chicken and sausage together then used the oil to sauté fresh spinach, mushrooms and a touch more garlic. I omitted the salt and used Cajun seasoning.  This recipe was still a little bland but the salt level was much better. I think I will try 1/2 teaspoon more seasoning next time and possibly cottage cheese.  The grittiness of the Ricotta is somewhat off putting for me.   I also used oven ready noodles (excellent idea) and 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes which gave no heat at all.  Next time I will use 1/2 tsp. 3.5 stars

1st try- Meh...  Use half spinach and salt.  Layer the way you choose.  Add a little crushed red pepper and it might be a little better.  Just ok but VERY labor intensive and takes way longer to prep than I would have guessed.  The worst part was reading the recipe directions.  Each step should be easily distinguishable and not crammed all in one paragraph.  Again, just OK.

To be fair, I made this recipe as written, except using only 1 package of spinach, b/c I did not pay close enough attention to the fact that it calls for 2. When it came to assembling this, I mixed the ricotta, spinach and chicken together, to make it easier.  This recipe is extremely good. I did use fat free milk and part skim cheeses, and you couldn't tell. It is still divine and delicious. The only complaint we had was, we felt it could use more salt and more garlic, so the next time I make this, I will add a lot more fresh garlic and extra salt.  This was even better the next day.

This is an incredible recipe. I have made twice now. The second time, I doubled the sauce (to make two 9x13 pans) and then realized (at the last minute) that I didn't have enough chicken broth. Because I didn't have enough sauce for the second 9x13 pan, I primarily used a pre-made red sauce (I love Classico brand). The result? It turned out fantastic. If you are short on time or ingredients, this recipe is delicious with a red sauce. P.S. I like adding a little bit of nutmeg to the white sauce...
