text:
This was a great recipe! Did tweek a bit. Added a pkg of fried, crumbled bacon (will add more next time) yum. only used one pkg of spinach (will use fresh next time as you couldn't taste it) and used more milk and chicken broth as it cooks pretty "contained" and we like it a little creamier. Many reviews stated they thought it was bland, so I used 2 cups mozz and 2 cups of 6 cheese Italian. Gave it a little extra zip. While I did cook chicken in the bacon grease...WOW...I also added some of the remnants of said grease to the sauce to add the bacon bits left in the bottom of the skillet. will def make again!!!

userID:
10248500
Display Name:
CaseyB
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been using Allrecipes for a LONGGGGGG time and have never had the inclination to write a review about a recipe until I cam across this one. IT WAS AMAZING!!!! I took the time to read some of the reviews and here are the additions/substitutions that I made:

Used Fresh spinach and also added fresh finely chopped mushrooms. I sauteed the two together with a little butter and EVOO. Once those were done cooking, I added the Ricotta. I used a little more than the recipe calls for because there is no such thing as too much cheese!!!!

For the sauce mixture, I used 2 cups of milk, 2 cups of broth and more garlic than it called for. Use as much garlic as your taste buds can handle... I also followed a previous tip to finely chop your onions while you cook the sauce. I finely chopped them and it added flavor without being "too chunky" of an onion taste.

I used 2cups of 6 cheese italian mixture and 2 cups of mozzarella instead of 4 cups of mozzarella, and used more parmesan than it called for. Again, the more cheese the better!

ALSO - I used FF ricotta, low fat butter, low fat cheeses (when possible), reduced sodium chicken broth, FF milk - - - dont get me wrong, this recipe isn't "healthy" but I cut back wherever possible and it was still amazing. 

I also used Tyson ready made grilled chicken strips. Heated them over the stove, then chopped them up in to small bite sized pieces and also used no boil lasagna noodles Barilla brand. 

DELICIOUS & will continue to use this recipe!

text:
With all the money and time spent I wouldn't make this again. My boyfriend liked it, I thought it was edible and my son did not care for it at all. I precooked the noodles, tripled the garlic, I cooked diced chicken breasts seasoned with salt, pepper, garlic powder and onion powder, used fresh spinach that I cooked with garlic and butter, added nutmeg to the sauce and spinach and layered it differently. Sauce, noodles, spinach and ricotta mixed together, 1/2 cup mozz cheese. Then noodles, sauce, chicken, 1/2 cup mozz cheese. Then noodles, rest of the sauce, 1 cup mozz cheese, parm cheese and fresh parsley. I didn't like the chicken layer. The texture and blandness of the chicken just was unappealing to me. I loved the spinach and ricotta layer and think I might try using that as a filling for manicotti and using the sauce to cook it in!

text:
With an overall total rating of nearly 5 stars, my husband and I expected a bit more flavor.  It is definitely rich--maybe a bit too rich for my family, and it is just too bland for us.  We even used an extra garlic clove.  Maybe if we try it again, aside from using lower fat cheeses or something to reduce the richness, we will experiment with more, and different seasonings.  But I am not so sure we would make this again.  It made me miss regular lasagna in that the red sauce at least gives more flavor. (An I do like white pizza by the way).  My husband though maybe sausage would be good in it with the chicken.  Just a starchy, heavy dish without much flavor.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe.  I made this for a group of friends and I received HIGH praise & several requests for the recipe.  I made a couple of changes:  I used 3 cups of chicken and about 1 3/4 boxes of spinach.  I love spinach but I wasn't sure all my guests would want to be overwhelmed with it. I used 2% milk and the sauce was plenty thick and creamy.  I did chop the onions in small pieces.  I added a bit more Parmesan cheese on top - and used a combination of shaved and shredded.  I cooked my chicken in my crock pot and I didn't have a lot of dirty dishes, as some reviewers did.  Following the directions, layering this easy to make dish was a breeze.  We had leftovers tonight and it was, as I suspected, BETTER the 2nd night than the first.  We have an Italian dish at least once a weeka nd this recipe will definitely become a part of our regular rotation.  I'm eager to try some additonal veggie additions such as carrots or artichoke.  Yum.

text:
This was my first lasagna ever!  My husband and I loved it, but it didn't go over quite as well with the kids as I had hoped.  It was worried when it came out of the oven that it was too runny/saucy, but it congealed as it rested.  Someone had written that it was too dry, which makes me wonder if they missed either the broth or the milk.  My husband detests ricotta, but I read a review where someone successfully substituted cottage cheese, so that is what I did.  I was worried about it being "weird", but it all melted down and you didn't even realize there was cottage cheese in it.  I used 1 package of spinach and it was plenty.  2 would have been too much.  Delish!

text:
While not your traditional lasagna, this was pretty darn good.  I cooked the sauce and prepared the lasagna during lunch, and just let it sit in the fridge until dinner.  This recipe can easily be made ahead of time, then cooked.  I too used no-boil lasagna noodles and they turned out just fine.  I also added LOTS more garlic than the recipe called for as well as freshly grated nutmeg over the spinach.  (I used one bag of fresh baby spinach, too, not the frozen kind.)  Very filling, but very good.  Thanks for a delicious recipe, Lisa!

text:
I put this in shells because that's what I had in the cupboard.  Instead of using spinach, I chopped up some broccoli, carrots, & asparagus, maybe 2- 2 1/2 cups of vegetables total.  Sauteed the onion, garlic & vegetables in the butter & made the sauce in there.  Left out the ricotta because I didn't have any and halved the mozzarella because sauce didn't seem to need it. Used about 1/2 cup of mozzarella cheese with the parmesean cheese for topping.  This made 2 8x8 pans of shells, fulling probably about 30 shells.  Oh my gosh, heaven in every bite!!!!

text:
Excellent!  Only made a few minor swaps.  I used cottage cheese in place of the ricotta (not a fan) and I only used one-third to half the amount of spinach it called for.   I mixed the spinach with the cottage cheese and added an egg to that mixture.  And I mixed the cubed chicken with the cheese sauce then I layered it as you would a regular lasagna.  I also used low-fat cottage cheese and low-fat mozzarella to save on the calories and fat.  Next time I will use a whole grain lasagna noodle to make it more healthy as well.  Will definately be saving this one!

I absolutely loved this recipe--it was exactly what I was looking for. It was the first time in probably 10 years I had made lasagna from scratch, but the recipe was easy to follow and it turned out perfectly.  Next time I make it, to save some time, I'll skip all of step 2 and its ingredients, and use store-bought sauce instead. I was halfway through before I realized I was making alfredo sauce from scratch! It was delicious, but took quite awhile.   I also used someone's earlier suggestion and cooked fresh spinach instead of frozen.   All in all, great white lasagna recipe!

text:
I think this would be much better if the recipe called for browned and drained Italian sausage rather than chicken, broccoli (in addition to the spinach), and if the white sauce had several cloves of roasted garlic blended into it.  The recipe as it stands was a bit bland, and the chicken was just kind of 'there'.  I used 2% milk and the sauce was super thick- I cannot imagine using whole milk. That said, I think the flour and butter could both be halved- saving a ton of carbs, calories, and fat.  I also ended up using only 2.5 cups of mozzarella altogether- using anymore would have just been gluttonous.

This was good but I don't think it was worth all of the work.  I suppose if you did it in stages, it might have been easier.  I was boiling chicken, making the sauce, and cooking the noodles all at the same time.  It took a long time to get dinner on the table.  When I work that hard, I want oohs and aahs. I would probably cut back on the mozz and add a little more parmesian on the top.  Also, it barely fit into my 13x9 pan.  I had to keep smashing it down as I was putting the layers together.

Yummy, but I omitted the chicken and did things a bit differently. text:
This recipe was not only wonderful, but it was fun to make. My husband jumped in and helped me with the layering. :) Here are my suggestions. 1 pkg of spinach was enough, but if you love spinach go for 2. Next time I make this I will cut the chicken into smaller pieces or even shred the chicken. The bit sized chunks I used seemed a little out of place in the dish. I chose to puree the onions instead of chopping and the sauce was smooth and delicious! I will also play with the layering a bit instead of following the recipe suggestions. I also think sauteed mushrooms would be amazing in this dish. This one is a keeper!

text:
Delicious!! soaked the lasagna noodles in hot water for about 30 min. cooked chicken in butter, garlic, chicken broth, Italian seasoning, red pepper flakes, salt n pepper. let cool and shredded. minced about 4 garlic cloves for the sauce and added red pepper flakes to taste, mixed ricotta and 10 oz. of spinach. Layers: sauce, 3 noodles, ricotta/spinach & chicken, sauce, 3 noodles, ricotta/spinach & chicken, sauce, 3 noodles, sauce, motz/parsley/parm. =D

text:
I loved this recipe. I'm not sure what everyone is complaining about the prep time for. I was in a hurry to get dinner on the table. So I did make a few changes. I left out the ricotta cheese, my husband doesn't like it, I also used rotini noodles. I didn't have spinach so I skipped them. Although to late I thought to add broccoli. I will add it next time. I then just added mixed everything together in the pot I used to make the white sauce. ON top I added the last of the cheese and put the lid on the pot to let the cheese melt. From start to finnish it took me 45 minutes to make it. Maybe a food processor would help people to cut down on the prep time. I just toss the cheese in and grind it instead of grating it. Once everything is melted you can't tell the difference.I put the noodles on to cook at the same time the chicken was cooking and while that was cooking I made the white sauce. As soon as the sauce was done I checked and the noodles and chicken were done so I drained the noodles and cut up the chicken. It was really very quick and easy.

text:
Pretty good "white" lasagna, although I prefer my recipe for rigatoni-broccoli bake with homemade alfredo sauce over this one....  As I do for all lasagna recipes that direct to cook the noodles beforehand, I soak mine in a large (i.e. 9x13 inch pan, or, better yet, a roasting pan) full of VERY hot tap water for about 20-30 minutes while I'm preparing the sauce.  Turns out great every time.  Instead of using cubed chicken breasts, I substituted a lemon-herb rotisserie chicken, deboned it and shredded the white meat (I saved the dark meat for another use).  Did everything else as directed.  My lasagna seemed "wet", but after cooling for 15 minutes, it thickened up.  I made this for Christmas Eve dinner.  I invited my bf, parents and another couple over for the festivities.  Problem was, my mom "had" to eat b/c she was starving, so my lasagna didn't have a chance to set.  The second helping was fine (not too saucy).  The homemade white sauce is just divine.  Thanks for sharing such a great, easy to prepare ahead of time, "special-occasion worthy" recipe!  I am now known as the lasagna queen. : )

I was a little nerveous to prepare this for a dinner party because I had never tried it!  It came out great!  My guests loved it and all wanted the recipe! It reminded me of an Alfredo Lasagna.  Very rich and creamy! I did a few things differently than the recipe stated. I used about 4 garlic cloves instead of 1, I used oven ready lasagna noodles and I used 1 package of spinach rather than 2.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I had to change my review to give it the five stars it more than deserves.  Originally, I gave it a reluctant four (Really deserves 100 stars) due to the kids and husband being less than enthusiastic about it. But, for lunch the next day (I went on strike), DH warmed some up, saying "It's So Much Better Today!!"  Over the next few days, I almost fell over when I saw the empty tupperware.  HE HAS NEVER WILLINGLY EATEN UP LEFTOVERS - EVER IN HIS LIFE.   I did short the chicken broth, as one reviewer suggested, and made up the rest with white wine.  Instead of individual spices, I just added Penzey's Pasta Sprinkle (garlic, basil, oregano and thyme), and finally:  FRESH spinach (I can't stand canned or frozen), ripped into small (kid-friendlier - if that's possible for Spinach) pieces.  Oh, and used PART-SKIM ricotta and mozzarella cheeses.

Wow! This is fantastic! My kids (11 & 4) gobbled it up and my husband raved. There is one thing I will change when I make it again and the reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars. I will add an egg to the ricotta as it was dry. I used fresh baby spinach (not cooked) and it was great (easier too). This is a keeper!

text:
This dish is absolutely delicious. The only thing I did differently, however, was after adding half the mozzerella and parmesan to the flour mixture I also added the chicken & spinach and mixed it all up. I then lined the pan with the lasagna noodles and spread the ricotta on top, then put 1/3 of the cheesy, spinachy, chicken mixture on top. I did this for two more layers and then added the remaining mozzarella and Parmesan to the top of the lasagna...it came out perfect!!

Great recipe, 5 stars because my husband and kids loved it. A little bland next time I will play with extra seasonings. Also mine was a little dry to me so I think I'll make and extra half batch of sauce and add it to the ricotta. I will also layer in a more traditional way as the chicken ricotta layer was dry and the spinach/sauce layer was wet. The consistency would be better if it was uniform. I used a Rotisserie chicken which was wonderful.

text:
My family and I loved this recipe.  The only change I made was to use the oven-ready lasagne noodles as I didn't have any of the others on hand.  It still turned out well.  Just have to watch how much sauce you have for the top layer of noodles since I barely had enough to cover them, but all I did was push them back down into the sauce when the top ones "bowed up" at bit toward the end of cooking.  My husband really liked the oven-ready as they were al dente in texture.  The flavors in this was very good and as others have said....this tasted even better the next day!!  We will be making this again.  Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
While this was good, I didn't find it great. The sauce was wonderful, and it was a nice change from the regular tomato sauce lasagna. I did what some other readers suggested and used half the spinach, mixed with the ricotta, and I agree the whole 20 ounces would have been too much. Though I seasoned the cooked chicken breast I used with cajun seasoning and even some extra cayenne pepper, I thought the dish needed an extra "something". The whole thing was rather sloppy, too, with layers spreading all over the place: I'm glad I didn't serve this to company. All in all a great idea, and a nice change of pace, but I doubt I'd make it again.

Deeeeeeelicious!!!! As rich as this recipes is, it is definitely a nice treat. I followed the recipe almost exactly. I only substituted Italian Blend seasonings in place of the oregano and basil and used 1 (10 oz.) package of spinach (which was plenty..imo). This was a good recipe, but I am still searching for a lasagna recipe that knocks my socks off. I also added 2 cloves of garlic instead of one and only half the spinach.  I found the lasagna to be better tasting the second time I reheated it.

country:
None
text:
A tip for lasagna with no bake noodles:  do NOT place them directly to the edges, and you dont have to overlap!!  Pasta absorbs water and grows in size when it cooks.  I made this recipe and the "sauce" was equivalent to about 2 pounds of melted cheese!  The ladagna was too dry.  I know it was my fault for thinking that the sauce was enough, but I would try this one again with my own alfredo sauce or one from this site.  Here's a tip:  Make the sauce according to these directions for layering, then POUR a thinner alfredo around the edges.

helpfulCount:
0
userID:
10547400
Display Name:
Jolynn Sullivan
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
31
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6027625.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have tried this recipe twice. The first time, I followed it exactly as is and it turned out to be a good meal. I would have rated it a 3/5 Stars. My family ate it and said that it was “okay” but, not a show stopper. The complaints were that there was way too much spinach and the chicken was a bit bland, too chunky and there wasn’t enough of it. I allowed it to cool for a bit before serving but, it still fell apart when it was dished out so the presentation wasn’t visually appealing. The second time that I made it I made a few adjustments that helped to boost the rating to 4/5 Stars. This time, I only used 1 package of spinach, a much better ratio according to my audience. I also marinated the chicken overnight in 1/4 c olive oil, 1 T minced garlic, 1/2 t coarse salt, 1/2 t ground pepper, 1/4 t oregano, 1/4 t basil, and 1 T fresh parsley. I grilled the chicken and then shredded it this time instead of cubing it like the recipe suggested. It seemed to blend in better this way and you didn’t end up biting into any big chunks of chicken. I added 1 beaten egg, 1/2 t salt and 1 t fresh parsley to the ricotta mixture. This seemed to help hold everything together nicely and made the presentation more appealing without a noticeable difference to the flavor of the dish. To summarize, I will make this recipe again with the alterations but, it didn’t go over well enough in my family to make it into our permanent rotation.

text:
I don’t necessarily agree that this was bland, but I do think that perhaps something key was missing from the dish. That said, it was tasty! Nice and cheesy. And a lot of work. I didn’t make very many changes but I did up the garlic to 1.5 teaspoons (1 tsp equals 1 clove). I didn’t use parsley on top but had so much spinach left over that I ended up sprinkling some on top in place of the parsley. I used chicken thighs cooked in olive oil. If I were to make this again, I might add some additional depth of flavor by adding mushrooms and/or perhaps even some spice with a sprinkling of hot pepper flakes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a larger/huge lasagna by adjusting this recipe. Increased the sauce by 50%.Used 12 lasagna noodles, a large container ricotta, and used much more mozzarella & parm. (I may try 15 noodles next time, 5 on three layers.) I increased garlic to 3 cloves & used all fresh herbs. I cooked up 16oz baby spinach and a large container mushrooms in two separate pans. I also cooked three large chicken breasts sprinkled with all seasoning in a pan too. I mixed the spinach, mushrooms & ricotta together. I layered sauce, then noodles, ricotta, chicken, sauce, mozzarella & parm twice and then a little sauce on top sprinkled with parm & fresh parsley. I also broiled the top after baking to brown.

city:

country:
None
text:
I used no boil noodles, but wouldn't recommend it, especially for the top layer of noodles because they didn't get soft enough and I had to poke holes and add at least 3/4 cup of broth the get it softer. I used a lot more basil, oregano, pepper and salt to get more flavor. I tasted the sauce until I loved it. The layering instructions were vague at first, but I ended up with sauce, noodles, all of the ricotta, I added roasted red pepper, all of the chicken, noodles, sauce, fresh chopped spinach (about 8 oz), cheeses, noodles, remaining sauce, dried parsley and cheese. I tented the lasagna until the end to brown. Served with a salad and garlic bread. I would make this again. It was flavorful to my liking and wasn't overly cheesy.

country:

text:
I was looking for a white chicken lasagna recipe and chose this one based on the homemade roux base and fresh chicken.  It was a good recipe and cheesy however too bland and would require adding some basic seasonings to the sauteed chicken in the pan (crushed black pepper/salt at the very least).  

Also, I did add crushed red pepper flakes, fresh parsley, and crushed black pepper to the roux .  As well as substituted fresh baby spinach over frozen spinach.  

My dinner guests enjoyed the white cheese chicken lasagna and two pieces were left that were up for grabs as leftovers!  Thank you for always providing a solid foundation and good recipes for us!

KimberlyDarby

text:
I followed the recipe to a T except I used Kettle & Fire chicken mushroom bone broth instead of chicken stock.  The white sauce for this recipe is TO DIE FOR and the lasagne was delicious, even my very picky teenage daughter loved it.   The only change I would make is, to use fresh spinach and sauté it with some olive or avocado oil, onion & garlic.  The frozen spinach has a nice texture in the recipe but in my opinion is a bit bland.  This is a keeper and if you’re looking for an impressive dish to bring to a potluck this is it!

text:
Great dish. Brought it to a Italian Heritage night dinner meeting, got rave reviews.
I substituted skinless,boneless chicken thighs sprayed with olive oil,  and seasoned with salt,  pepper,  and garlic powder and baked in the oven at 325 for 25 minutes. Cubed the chicken thighs after cooking. I also substituted rigatoni macaroni for lasagna, lots easier to serve.
Frank Gates
Hertford, NC

Being on a gluten-free diet makes it difficult to have pasta in my diet. But when I found gluten-free, oven-ready lasagna I thought I had found a solution. I made a lasagna with a recipe on the pasta box and it was pretty good. Then this white lasagna came in my AllRecipies.com Email and I thought I'd give it a try. Unfortunately, the white sauce was not moist enough to cook the lasagna and it came out hard and chewy. In addition, the sauce was rather bland, even with all that cheese. I grated my own mozzarella and parmesana so those were fresh, I love ricotta and was looking forward to having lasagna with real ricotta. After all that anticipation, I was really disappointed.

text:
Gluten-Free adapted and delicious! I use Tinkyada rice pasta and Pamela's GF flour mix to substitute any recipe with excellent results. **Slightly under cook the Tinkyada lasagna noodles, drain, and fill pot with cool water until ready to assemble. They are easier to handle with less breaking.** I combine the chicken/ricotta/cheese sauce together like CARDOZOS suggested for easier layering. I also use fresh, RAW spinach  -- NO cooking it ahead of time. It always turns out excellent, but I suggest greasing your pan very well. I've made this several times with little tweaks  (like sauteing mushrooms with the onion) Delicious every time!!

text:
Followed the recipe to the letter, didn't change a thing. (That's the only way I review recipes anymore. Makes zero sense to make a dozen alterations and then review my own unique recipe. That helps no one.)

I honestly preferred the bites without a chicken chunk in it. Think I will use half the amount of chicken next time, dice them smaller, or use none at all and just serve chicken breast on the side. Honestly though, I had cooked, diced, and refrigerated the chicken breast over 24 hours prior because I had originally planned to use it for something different, and I think that made a difference in how the chicken tasted in the lasagna. I think the chicken needs to be used super fresh, right away after cooking, unrefrigerated. I also prefer cottage cheese to ricotta in my lasagna. Will go back to that next time as well.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a dish I make for guests and my gentleman.

I found a couple ways to make this less messy and labor intensive
1. I use no boil lasagna noodles
2. I make 1 1/2 times the Alfredo sauce for the absorption in the pasta, it prevents the dish drying out using the no boil pasta.
3. I'm not a fan of picking spinach out of my teeth when entertaining. I layer it with smaller cut broccoli flowerets, thicker cut sliced fresh mushrooms and loads of chicken.

Use whatever you like in the sauce. Follow your personal tastes in cheeses, garlic, etc.

country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  Not for the dairy intolerant though.  And with the prep time, I wouldn't make it after work as a weeknight meal.  Having said that though, it really was delish!

I made some modifications based on other reviewers....
--First, I used a 10 oz bag of fresh spinach sautéed in olive oil with salt and pepper instead of frozen spinach.
--Second, I used oven ready lasagna noodles.
--Third, I added 1 tsp nutmeg to the sauce because spinach and bechemel sauce needs nutmeg.
--Fourth, I added a layer of sautéed vegetables.  Specifically, I added 1 c. Shredded carrots, 1 c. Chopped zucchini, and 8 oz sliced mushrooms.  I sautéed in olive oil with salt and pepper.
--Lastly, I used rotisserie chicken. 

My husband loved it!  When I asked him what would he change he said, "why would you change anything.  It's perfect!"  Quite the endorsement!

text:
While the flavor is amazing, it's just too rich.  I always substitute butter with coconut solid oil and milk with coconut milk for all dishes and casseroles I make. The difference is unbelievable.  Basically you don't feel like you're faking to keel over st the end of consumption.  I can't even imagine it being worse with the bitter and the milk. Recipes like this are responsibility for heart disease and our obesity epidemic in this country.  Also I'm too old to be eating something this over saturated.  With that said, I am still glad I made it cause indefinitely will revamp.  I will reduce the mozzarella cheese to the sauce and half that.  I will make the layer with the spinach with mushrooms and replace the third mozzarella layer to zucchini yellow and green squash and perhaps add some carrots or broccoli.  I would also add more chicken as the chicken tasted great in that sauce.

Display Name:
Mike H

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
2 nights after fixing it, everything came together and melded and it was amazing.    As written it is probably a 4.0, but it is a good stepping stone to something even better.  I followed step 1 as written, leave cooked noodles covered in cold water until ready for them.  I followed step 2 as written, but put 20 oz of fresh, chopped spinach in to wilt with onions after they had softened, added 1-2 cups of fresh portabella mushrooms, 1 tablespoon minced garlic (jar) then continued with remaining step 2.  I think you can probably do it either way - combine spinach with onions or layer separately.

For step 3 I have never been a big Ricotta fan.  By itself it is pretty bland.  For this recipe I combined 2 cups Ricotta with one cup cottage cheese and 1 cup of feta cheese.  After the flavors melded it gave more depth to the cheese layer flavor.  I used 4 cups cubed rotisserie chicken with skin and drippings and added McCormick's  Montreal Chicken Seasoning to give the chicken more kick.  Naturally I also doubled the herbs.   I layered as per the recipe and used a 9 x 13" aluminum foil dish, BUT one with 4 inch sides instead of the usual low sided glass casseroles.   That was the only way to get the recipe into one pan and it worked GREAT!!  It was good from the very 1st night - but was amazing by the 3rd night.  The chicken had great flavor and punch, and the cheese was sophisticated and sublime.   I may never go back to Italian lasagna again!  Try chicken sausage next time instea

userID:
3639136
Display Name:
Christine in Virginia
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
24
recipesCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a jumping off point for my own version of chicken lasagna.  I think it came out fantastic with my modifications.  First of all, I used six oven-ready lasagna noodles and made the dish in two layers instead of three.  I made the white sauce with 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup flour, tons of garlic, onion powder, salt, pepper, basil, 1.5 cups of milk, 1/2 cup white wine, and 1.5 cups of broth.  Once it bubbled and thickened I stirred in 1/3 cup of grated parmesan, 2 cups shredded chicken, and one box of chopped frozen spinach (that I cooked ahead and squeezed all the excess water out of).  I set this mixture aside. I did not add ANY of the mozzarella to the white sauce. Then, I mixed 2.5 cups of ricotta with 2 beaten eggs, 1/2 cup of grated parmesan, salt, pepper, and a little garlic powder (the addition of eggs makes the ricotta bind a bit better and makes it bake fluffier in the dish).  I sprayed a 9X13 pan with cooking spray and laid three oven-ready noodles across the bottom,  I then layered half my ricotta mixture, one third of the shredded mozzarella, and then half of the milk/chicken/spinach mix.  I repeated this layer one more time and then used the final third of the cheese on top.  I baked it covered for 30 minutes and then uncovered for 25 more (at 375 degrees).  The final lasagna was luscious and loaded with flavor!  I think changing the layer construction, using less spinach, more garlic, eggs, and wine in place of some of the broth greatly improves
Review:

text:
This is a definite keeper (had 5 different foodie friends try it) with the modifications I made. FRESH spinach & mushrooms for starters. Also had to completely improvise on how I cooked my chicken, as this recipe gives no info on that, other than how much. I went super simple, as to keep the flavor a true to the recipe. A little olive oil in my pan and salt and peppered four chicken breasts only! Also, took them out after they were still slightly pink (not fully cooked) as to not dry out my meat, knowing they'd keep cooking through as they rested. And once in sauce, they'd finish completely! Great plan, the chicken was moist and delicious!

I absolutely loved this recipe!  It took about one hour to prep everything and another half hour to assemble the layers, but definitely worth the effort.  The next time I have company I will definitely be serving this dish.  Note:  I made sure I squeezed all the moisture out of the spinach by hand after I defrosted and drained both boxes of spinach to make sure the sauce didn't get watered down.

None
text:
This was so yummy! It has lotsa flavour. 

I used 400g of fresh spinach, 4 cloves of garlic, 18 noodles, 2 lb chicken, and sprinkled the spinach and ricotta layer with generous amount of garlic salt and Italian seasoning. 

I split the lasagna into two batches 10x8x3 and froze one. To cook: thaw for 2 days. Bake 350 covered for 60 minutes and uncovered 450 for 10.

text:
I boiled 3 chicken breasts in chicken broth before shredding it to give it extra flavor. Then, I boiled the spinach in the the leftover broth ( making sure it was very well drained before using). Since my family loves garlic (can't stress this enough), I added a an extra clove to saute and a teaspoon of garlic powder to the sauce. I also made an herb bread from this site to go with it. I can't even begin to tell you how amazing my house smelled! This recipe was a huge hit! Definitely going in the recipe box.

text:
I'm by no means a health-nut, nor a super experienced cook but I can hold my own in the 'general' realm....just a regular guy, so keep that in mind.  I made per the instructions, and the very bland, dry cubed chicken breast was THE ingredient that totally down-turned this recipe.  Otherwise, it has a superb flavor.  Next time I will boil up my usual skinless chicken quarters with onion and garlic salt, de-bone and make from there.  The breast totally ruined this for me - ZERO flavor there.  But, I will try this again with my chicken because in my experience I think this COULD be good....really.

region:

country:
None
text:
I have a larger lasagna pan (this would not fit in a 9x13 pan) and use 12 noodles soaked in boiling water for 30 minutes and layered lengthwise and crosswise alternately in the pan.  One package of frozen leaf spinach, thawed, drained and cut up with kitchen shears, is perfect.  It is a time-consuming dish but worth the effort.  Served with a salad and bread,  my family loved it - even the little kids ate it and asked for seconds.  Leftovers are just as good.  It is a keeper for me.

This turned out quite nicely! I especially loved the cream sauce. It was different. 

Admittedly I misunderstood the directions and didn't cook the chicken before baking in the lasagna. I got worried but it was too late to turn back. So I turned down the temp slightly and made sure I cooked to an internal temp of art least 180 degrees Fahrenheit. It turned out great and was cooked through and moist! 

Will definitely do again and next time possibly add bacon.

I thought this was good, but I made a few changes and will again. I don't like frozen spinach so I used a package of spinach. I will probably wilt it next time in a little bit of chicken broth next time to save room in the casserole pan. I used the recommended amount ricotta, but felt like that was a little too much.  I think a slightly thinner sauce by using more broth would have been perfect. I also recommend adding mushrooms to the spinach layer. I used the leftover baby portobellos we had and it was delicious in this recipe.

text:
This lasagna was amazing. My family loved it and my husband says I must make it again. I used Ali gradients but as another user suggested, to make it easier I used a large bowl and mixed my chicken, ricotta cheese, spinach, and added cream cheese (just because my husband loves cream cheese in any cheese based recipes) so I didn't have to layer it. I also mixed my milk with heavy whipping cream to thicken up the sauce since I was afraid the chicken broth would leave it too thin. It was amazing and I'msure if I followed the exact recipe I would still feel the same as my changes were just for personal touches but didn't really modify the original recipe much. I will definitely make this again. It tastes so much better when it's eaten as leftovers.

text:
I am giving this 2 stars as there were a couple of people in my house that loved this recipe, the rest asked why I didn't just make my lasagna. I wasn't impressed at all. I followed it exact, something I rarely do and probably shouldn't have this time. I found it to be too bland, and adding the cheese into the sauce was a horrible choice in my opinion,but the sauce itself needed a lot of help in the flavor department, perhaps some sauteed bell peppers would have helped there as well as fresh herbs.  I found it lacking texturally as well, the mouth feel completely turned me off, I couldn't distinguish the layers I expect in a lasagna. Maybe with more veggies in the layers to give it some bite and some variety in flavor would improve it greatly, but over all just found this to be a disappointment and will not be making it again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made a few adjustments to this recipe...but hosted a dinner party (informal)with both kids and adults and it was a huge hit!  I made this in a 10*15 casserole dish....1.5x recipe.  I used 5 huge garlic cloves crushed (fresh)...I sautéed 2 1 lb boxes of baby spinach (stems removed)- I also tried to squeeze the spinach after cooling to remove excess water.  I used fresh basil and oregano.  I used part skim ricotta, mozzarella.  I used freshly grated Romano cheese instead of Parmesan.  Also, I used Seasoned Rotisserie Chicken (from Costco)...but from anywhere would work.  I found I needed to cook this for an hour, perhaps because it was larger in size and no cook lasagna noodles.  Will definitely make again!

region:

country:
None
text:
Several years ago at a conference, I was served the most divine white sauce chicken lasagna and have been looking for it's match ever since.  I think that this recipe could serve as the base for my dream lasagna.  First made just as instructed, my family liked this but thought it was more like a chicken casserole than a lasagna and ended up spooning generous dallops of pesto over our servings to liven the dish up.  So, second time around I added 1cup of pesto in with the ricotta mix.  It was near perfect with the addition of pesto.  My son and I still spooned a bit more over our servings and the man did not, all agreed that the recipe was greatly improved with the abundance of basil, pine nuts and olive oil from the adding the fresh pesto.  This dish is deliciously rich as written, we thought it just lacked the flavor to match and think the pesto corrects the balance to near perfection.  Those painfully aware of fats could reduce butter in the sauce to counter some of the oil in the pesto.  We will make again with the changes to suit our taste and am thankful to have found this great base recipe!
Review:

text:
This recipe was yummy!!  But it took me over two hours to make and as another rater said, I used so many dishes to make this recipe.  Make sure you use the no-boil noodles.  It really does save time and mess.  I also used fresh spinach which was very tasty. I sauteed it in some of the butter along with mushrooms and basil. I would recommend only using one bag of spinach.  When layered with the mushrooms, it's plenty.  I also used cottage cheese for the ricotta. When the recipe states to layer 1/3 noodles, the ricotta, and the chicken, it means ALL the chicken, and ALL the ricotta.  I misunderstood and only put 1/3 of each only to find out I had to throw it in somewhere else.  I will make this again with my changes which should make the whole meal prep much faster.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The lasagna was fantastic.

The recipe needs a little tweaking though.

For example, you need 12 noodles for a 9x13 pan. Any less and you have 1 inch gaps between them.

Second, the layering directions could be a little more clear: ...Layer with 1/3 of the noodles, ALL OF the ricotta, and ALL OF the chicken. Arrange 1/3 of the noodles over the chicken, and layer with 1/3 of the sauce mixture, ALL OF THE spinach...
(Reason being, people who KNOW how to make lasagna don't need much of a step-by-step.)

A 'medium' saucepan is insufficient to properly stir the ingredients. In reality, to have enough room to maneuver, you need a very large saucepan.

Other than that, this recipe is solid, and the result is awesome (if you figured all the above out beforehand).
Review:
Rating:
5

Wow!  I decided to give this a try and was really impressed. It's a definite keeper. The changes I made was to use ground chicken instead of cubed chicken since I already had some in the freezer. I seasoned the chicken with Italian herbs and it gave the meat a really nice flavor. I also used less ricotta cheese than the recipe called for since I'm not a huge fan of ricotta. I also added some diced mini Bella  mushrooms and diced red bell pepper that were sautéed.  Lastly, I used fresh spinach instead of frozen because I already had some in the fridge.  Fantastic!

text:
This is a very nice white sauce.  Made this lasagna for my family and they really liked it; will be making it for guests this weekend.   I tweaked it by stirring 2 lightly beaten eggs into the ricotta. The eggs make the ricotta more spreadable.  Used 1/2 Lb fresh spinach, parboiled & well drained, instead of frozen spinach. The fresh spinach is so much tastier than frozen and no more work.  Lastly, I used ground chicken which I sautéed with 1 cup cooked onion and a little fresh garlic; we love ground chicken and it is great for casseroles.   Think I will add a little white wine to the sauce for another flavor dimension next time.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I took the advice of the reviewer that suggested starting with a bacon (I just used 3 slices).  I used a small portion of the bacon grease for all of my skillet work:  to cook the chicken, to wilt the fresh spinach instead of using frozen, and even to sautee the onions/garlic (I used a little less butter than called for).  I crumbled the bacon over the cubed chicken layer in the lasagna.  Because it was just a few slices, it did not give the lasagna any distinguishable bacon flavors, but it did make the dish a little more flavorful overall.  Big hit!

text:
This is AMAZING. I'm eating it right now. I made just a few tiny changes: used 8 oz of fresh spinach from the bag, vs. 20 (!!!) oz of frozen, and also used fat free ricotta cheese. I covered it to bake for 30 minutes, and then baked it another 15 or so uncovered because the darn noodles on top didn't want to cook (I used no boil). I will DEFINITELY make again!!!! maybe next time use a tad less salt. If I remember correctly, I didn't even use quite the called-for amount of salt as it was, so next time I'll probably use 1/2 teaspoon. :) Amazing recipe!!!!!!

text:
Anytime a recipe comes along that my 9 year old daughter likes I praise the allrecipes gods.  My daughter only loves potatoe products and chicken nuggets.  She loved this recipe and even though she initially tried to pick around the spinach, I got her to eat that too without any problems.  The recipe was easy to follow, I got boneless, skinless chicken thighs and use my scissors to cut it into squares.  I could not blend the flour, butter, onions and get it to bubble without pouring in the broth it will burn.  Use a whisk.  I also used non boil noodles and it all turned out awesome.  I also added an egg to the ricotta and seasoned it lightly with SeasonAll.  The whole process took about 2 1/2 hours but well worth it.

The family really enjoyed this one, as did I!  I added 1 extra clove of garlic (garlic flavor was pretty strong but we like it that way), heaping teaspoons of basil and parsely, and an extra 1/2 teaspoon of oregano.  I also had a little more than 2 cups of cooked chicken and some extra cheese (we used parmesan, ricotta, and a four cheese italian blend instead of plain mozzerella).  YUM!  It came out cheesy and delicious.      It probably would have been great without all the extras also!

I am going to have to agree with some other reviews and say that as written, this recipe was a bit disappointing.  I really like the idea of a white lasagna, but I followed the recipe to a tee and it came out bland.  Perhaps less than 2 packets of frozen spinach as other reviewers suggested would help. I made this recipe almost exactly as written for my birthday cookout. I did use the fresh bag of spinach with stems removed, cooked in 1 Tbs. olive oil quickly. I also never use Ricotta Cheese. I used Cottage Cheese in it's place. Added fresh parmesan cheese and tons of garlic and more chicken then called for. It was a HUGE hit!  I froze it and it turned out fine.  Just took longer too cook then expected. Was well worth the wait.  No leftovers!

text:
I made this with servings for 6.  I don't think the ingredients all translated correctly b/c the directions were not accurate,but all in all, it turned out great.  I would recommend making a little extra cheese sauce by adding more broth and milk.  I ended up needing more and had to pour milk around the edges to keep the layers saturated.  I also increased the fresh garlic and used fresh basil because I had some one hand.  I also grated a sprinkle of fresh nutmeg in the cheese sauce and it gave it a nice touch. Loved all the flavors!  Served with soft, garlic bread.  Reheats nicely.

text:
This was good.  I cut the recipe in half and thought 1 cup of ricotta was too much, and less spinach would have been better.  Like others I added extra garlic. I also added sauteed mushrooms and mixed everything together as one sauce.  In doing this I needed to add a little extra broth to thin it out a little.  I also made the lasagna in advance (minus the topping), so I baked it for 50 minutes.  I added some mozzarella, parmesan and parsley on top the last 20 minutes.  I'm only giving this 4 stars because I think it's a lot of work, yet it's not great.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe makes an excellent lasagna.  I altered two things just to speed things up. And although I wouldn't do them again, I'll mention them so that others don't make the same mistakes or at least know what to expect.  First, I used already cooked and cubed chicken breast.  If you do this, keep in mind that is a lot of added salt.  Second, if using the no-cook noodles you might want to make your sauce a little thinner is you want a saucier casserole.  Based on another review, I sauteed 2 bags of fresh spinach in  place of frozen and added fresh mushrooms.  I will definitely make this again but I'll cook my own chicken and use regular noodles.

I won't be making again.  My husband didn't have to choke it down but neither of us was impressed.

userID:

Display Name:
christinacooks
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this simple recipe. To make it even easier, I cooked 2 chicken breasts in a skillet with chicken broth (add a little flavor to the chicken) and used that broth for the cream sauce. After I poured off the broth, I shredded the chicken and added 1 pkg of frozen spinach to the chicken (it was a lot of spinach!) and let it heat gently in the pan with the chicken. I did add a can of diced tomatoes, for color more than anything.  I recommend more garlic - I used 4 cloves in the cream sauce and tossed in 2 more with the spinach/chicken mixture.  This recipe is easy and definitely a winner. Very easy to understand. The directions are very clear and produce fabulous results. Don't hesitate about trying this one!!  Possible changes: Omit ricotta if you don't like it. Add the mozzarella here instead of mixing it into the sauce. Add portabello mushrooms or roasted red pepper. Myhusband said add pepperoni. I wouldn't advise it ;-)

text:
This is a very labor intensive recipe so make sure you have alot of time to prepare, but it is well worth it in my opinion.  The only change I make is to use fresh baby spinach.  My casserole dish is overflowing in the end and I have to keep pushing it down.  This is also a rich and heavy recipe, so if you are looking for something light this is not the recipes for you.  I have made this for several years now and my family loves it.  Do not omit the garlic & onions they are what give the sauce most of the wonderful flavor.  Thanks for sharing this one!  It's a keeper!

text:
Wow. This is outstanding.  I also had a little bit of trouble following the directions and thought they were a little tedious. Plus, staring with cooking the chicken, making the sauce and assembling the lasagna DID take a long time. It took me a good hour and a half. In the end, it was all worth it.  I stayed pretty true to the ingredients, but I used half of the amount of spinach and I used a "pizza cheese" blend instead of the plain mozzarella. The blend had smoked mozzarella, and it seems to have helped ramp up the flavor a little.  I will definitely make this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This, to me, is a 4 star recipe because it needed a little help.  The taste is pretty good.  Like a few others, I shredded the chicken.  Definitely don't use plain chicken.  Also, the spinach layer is too spinachy.  I suggest mixing the spinach with the ricotta or something.  I had a feeling the ricotta would be too plain, so I mixed in an egg and some s&p and parsley.  I just wish I had followed my instinct with the spinach!  I used the 2 C Mozzarella in the sauce, and didn't use the other 2 C.  The parm & ricotta was enough for the other layers.  Pretty tasty, it will probably be better in the morning.  OH, and I used NO bake lasagna noodles.  That probably saved a lot with the prep time.  It didn't seem to take too long.  I cooked it for 40 mins covered, and then 10 mins uncovered at 425.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had leftover chicken so I decided to try this recipe. I followed it as written. I used Barilla rolled flat lasagne noodles & didn't boil them. Each layer of four fit perfectly in the 9 x 13 pan. At first it looked like there was way too much in the pan. I thought for sure that the ingredients were going to overflow. But,  it baked down to being even with the top of the pan. The lasagne smelled so delicious as it baked. When I took it out of the oven, I commented that "It looked like it was from a restaurant". My grown children must have smelled it outside because they happened to drop by just as it finished baking (45 min.). They said that the finished product ""looked like something from the Olive Garden". After tasting it, they said that it "tasted like something from Olive Garden". Almost everyone had seconds. I'm just glad that there is enough left for my lunch today. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

text:
I made this last night and it was amazing! It is extremely rich and very cheesy.

I am so lucky I found this recipe. I'm not the greatest cook, but I felt like one last night.

Just so you learn from my experience: Make sure to defrost the spinach before you get to work on this. I had to run it under hot water because I forgot to take it out earlier. Also, I'm sure pre-packaged chicken chunks would make this recipe even easier.

I wish I could give it more stars!

text:
I was originally going to give it 4 stars since it wasn't quite the "WOW" recipe I expected, but after I took some leftovers to work for some coworkers I knew I had to give it 5 stars. They were drooling over it and demanded the recipe. My husband, who despises spinach, ate it willingly and even voluntarily took leftovers for lunch the next day. Only "changes" I really made were to use the shredded meat off a whole broiler chicken, only one package of spinach instead of 2, whole wheat lasagna instead of the standard lasagna, and cottage cheese instead of ricotta. Next time I make this, I will take the advice of other reviewers and mix the chicken, spinach, and sauce together instead of keeping them separate.

text:
I loved this recipe, and can't wait to try the leftovers. I just tweaked a few things as suggested by your reviews, and it was wonderful. I marinated my chicken breasts in Italian dressing before baking them in the oven. I also added a few more cloves of garlic and used leeks instead of onions because I'm not a huge onion fan. I only used one package of spinach and mixed it with the ricotta. I also layered it a bit different: I did sauce, noodles, ricotta/spinach, chicken, cheese, sauce, then another layer of the same, and topped that with the remaining sauce and cheese!! Definitely 5 stars from me.

text:
I made this for dinner last night - and while I would have rated it three stars, my DH liked it more than I did (as did my toddler), so it gets 4 stars. I changed a few things though, here's what I did. I used 3 large cloves of garlic, 1-10oz box of frozen chopped spinach and only 1/2 tsp each of dried basil and oregano (I think if I'd added the whole amount....the herbs would have been overwhelming). The end result was good, but I found it pretty rich. Given that my son and DH liked it so much, I will likely make it again, but if it were just me...I probably wouldn't.

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe a lot. I switched out ground chicken for chicken breast because it's what I happened to have on hand, but I don't think it adversely affected the flavor at all.  I halved the recipe, but I thought that half an onion was too much. I found the sauce to be very thick and somewhat difficult to work with, but the taste more than compensated.  It was amazing! I thought everything about the recipe was great, ESPECIALLY the sauce, which was rich and quite flavorful (I didn't find it bland at all, and it wasn't *too* rich, just right).  I think it's a great variation to typical lasagna.  I only gave it 4 stars because my husband liked the recipe, but said he'd still prefer red sauce lasagna.  Oh and I put the lasagna under the broiler for the last 2 or 3 mins and it made the top all bubbly and golden - awesome!

text:
This recipe was really good.  I don't know why some of the other reviews said that it was bland, because it really has a great flavor.  I made it for guests and they all devoured it.  Even my picky husband had a big serving of the leftovers the next day.  Trust me, if he goes for leftovers, it's a big success!  The reason I am only giving it 4 stars, is because it did come out pretty greasy on top, which I had to mop up with a paper towel before presenting it to my guests.  Now, part of that could have been my fault because I made it the night before and refrigerated it before baking, and the cooling down process could have caused the grease to separate while baking, but other than that, it was teriffic and I will DEFINITELY be making this again.

This recipe is a nice change from the usual lasagna.  Our preschool kids didn't really care for this but the adults liked it alot.  I had my husband grill up some chicken breasts and I then shredded them up.  The spices we used to season the chicken plus the smoky flavor from grilling really gave the chicken alot of flavor.  I used a bit more garlic than called for and used only 16 oz of spinach which was plenty.  I also added some cajun seasoning to the white sauce for added flavor since it seemed a bit bland when I first tasted it.  I think next time I will try adding the bacon someone mentioned.

UPDATE:  Added fresh basil and bacon to the lasagna and it was wonderful.  Definately a really nice twist to the recipe.
